subject: Added in JSON format for test report log, and ability to prevent deleting the log between runs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-11-20 23:26:43.000000000', 'files': ['patrole_tempest_plugin/rbac_rule_validation.py', 'patrole_tempest_plugin/config.py', 'patrole_tempest_plugin/plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/patrole/commit/ecf2d464bed3c43bc5f56d96a36e0f1f261b8cb7', 'message': 'Added in JSON format for test report log, and ability to prevent
deleting the log between runs

Added Role as a variable to be printed in the report log

Added in 2 new variables:
report_log_format: text (the default) or JSON
  In JSON format, the log will print the test results as a JSON
  object rather than a plaintext string

  Example:
  [Role]: admin, [Service]: nova, [Test]: test_create_agent, [Rules]:
os_compute_api:os-agents, [Expected]: Allowed, [Actual]: Allowed
  vs
  {"role": "admin", "service": "nova", "test": "test_create_agent",
"rules": "os_compute_api:os-agents", "expected": "Allowed", "actual":
"Allowed"}

  In the case where another string is present, the behavior
  defaults to the text-based line display

remove_log_on_run: True (the default) or False
  Controls whether or not to remove the log file on each invocation
  of tempest. This can be useful to preserve when multiple invocations
  are needed, to test multiple roles for example

Change-Id: I7a302e571f4fb5ffb33287c8153be7f8b8e38dc8
'}]
commit_message:
Added in JSON format for test report log, and ability to prevent
deleting the log between runs

Added Role as a variable to be printed in the report log

Added in 2 new variables:
report_log_format: text (the default) or JSON
  In JSON format, the log will print the test results as a JSON
  object rather than a plaintext string

  Example:
  [Role]: admin, [Service]: nova, [Test]: test_create_agent, [Rules]:
os_compute_api:os-agents, [Expected]: Allowed, [Actual]: Allowed
  vs
  {"role": "admin", "service": "nova", "test": "test_create_agent",
"rules": "os_compute_api:os-agents", "expected": "Allowed", "actual":
"Allowed"}

  In the case where another string is present, the behavior
  defaults to the text-based line display

remove_log_on_run: True (the default) or False
  Controls whether or not to remove the log file on each invocation
  of tempest. This can be useful to preserve when multiple invocations
  are needed, to test multiple roles for example

Change-Id: I7a302e571f4fb5ffb33287c8153be7f8b8e38dc8

commit_message:
Enable sphinx.ext.intersphinx for tempest

This package is used for automatic generation of links
to the documentation of objects in other projects.

Adding a mapping for the Tempest  makes it possible to
convert a reference like :py:class:`tempest.test.BaseTestCase`
to the link:
https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/library/code/tempest.test.html#tempest.test.BaseTestCase

Depends-On: I9a843ea024e71fbb377de5aa57cedafdd456269d

Change-Id: I946e78d4360a273e7fac23ac2cf879acb613da66

commit_message:
Role usage refactoring

Loading roles from config in one place. Fixing the issue with loading
roles from rbac_test_role and rbac_test_roles options.
Checking for admin role moved into RbacUtilsMixin class. In a stage when
the _init_roles is called It verifies the admin role ID for all roles,
including implied roles.
Added an ability to restore original roles if used pre-provisioned
credentials.
Modifying the PolicyAutority for taking a test_object to use is_admin
function in the _is_admin_context function.

TODO:
* unit tests
* functional test for pre-provisioned credentials ??? if i will figure
  out how to do this.

Change-Id: I4add0d24548163254f0e3051b38391dfe9948c28

commit_message:
Support both rbac_test_role and rbac_test_roles
in tempest.conf.
Resolved, user is assigned admin role irrespective of what value is given
to rbac_test_role in tempest.conf

Change-Id: Ie74525ce4c43c1a7d9bfec7cfd21926e90826d74

Missing policies:
* `insert_rule` for "Insert rule into a firewall policy" action [0]
* `remove_rule` for "Remove rule from firewall policy"  [1]

Add FWaaS client to avoid failed patrole-plugin-* jobs when
neutron-fwaas moves its Tempest tests into a separate plugin.
The neutron-fwaas plugin still doesn't abide by [2].

[0] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html#insert-rule-into-a-firewall-policy
[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html#remove-rule-from-firewall-policy
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/split-tempest-plugins.html#current-state-anticipated-impact

commit_message:
Add missing FWaaS tests

Missing policies:
* `insert_rule` for "Insert rule into a firewall policy" action [0]
* `remove_rule` for "Remove rule from firewall policy" action [1]

[0] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html#id370
[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html#id375

Depends-On: I979edd26264ae5f9ceab2da350bc99c40145ec40
Story: 2002641

added_lines: class BaseFWaaSV2PluginRbacTest(BaseNetworkRbacTest): """Base class to be used with tests that require FWaaS v2 extension """ @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(BaseFWaaSV2PluginRbacTest, cls).skip_checks() if not cls.is_fwaas_plugin_avaliable(): msg = ("FWaaS v2 Extension not installed.") raise cls.skipException(msg) @classmethod def is_fwaas_plugin_avaliable(cls): try: import neutron_fwaas # noqa return True except ImportError: return False @classmethod def _create_client(cls, klass, manager): return klass( manager.auth_provider, CONF.network.catalog_type, CONF.network.region or CONF.identity.region, endpoint_type=CONF.network.endpoint_type, build_interval=CONF.network.build_interval, build_timeout=CONF.network.build_timeout, **manager.default_params) @classmethod def get_client_manager(cls, credential_type=None, roles=None, force_new=None): manager = super(BaseFWaaSV2PluginRbacTest, cls).get_client_manager( credential_type=credential_type, roles=roles, force_new=force_new ) # Create FWaaS v2 clients if cls.is_fwaas_plugin_avaliable(): from neutron_fwaas.tests.tempest_plugin.services import v2_client cls.fwaas_groups_client = cls._create_client( v2_client.FirewallGroupsClient, manager) cls.fwaas_policies_client = cls._create_client( v2_client.FirewallPoliciesClient, manager) cls.fwaas_rules_client = cls._create_client( v2_client.FirewallRulesClient, manager) return manager

commit_message:
Allow testing of neutron plugins

Added a subclass of policy_authority to allow Neutron extensions to
be tested with Patrole, with the expectation that these tests would
live in the Neutron plugins, as in tempest plugins for the
Neutron extensions.

Depends-on: I498c637da9dac7605851b2edbbfb302103c3d6a9

Change-Id: I13e1b4223cff5efe008cb7207304a51d04e7a6ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/94/659894/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Validate whether the service or extension passed to ``__init__`` exists. deleted_lines: """Validate whether the service passed to ``__init__`` exists.""" cls.available_services = [s['name'] for s in services]

commit_message:
Add tests to cover segment_id attribute in subnets

Test gets and creates subnets with assigned segment [0].
Part of "Increase Neutron RBAC Coverage" initiative [1].

'create_subnet:segment_id'
'get_subnet:segment_id'

[0] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html#segments
[1] https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2002641

Story: 2002641
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584601/
Change-Id: I5606b833a46e3b548e44daf236d2f5b357859abd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/88/582388/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import netaddr @utils.requires_ext(extension='segment', service='network') @decorators.idempotent_id('c02618e7-bb20-1a3a-83c8-6eec2af08752') @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="neutron", rule="get_subnet:segment_id") def test_show_subnet_with_segment_id(self): """Show subnet with segment_id. RBAC test for the neutron "get_subnet:segment_id" policy """ net = self.create_network() self.addCleanup(self.networks_client.delete_network, net['id']) seg = self.segments_client.create_segment(network_id=net['id'], network_type="gre", segmentation_id=1234) self.addCleanup( self.segments_client.delete_segment, seg['segment']['id']) subnet = self.create_subnet(net, segment_id=seg['segment']['id'], cidr=netaddr.IPNetwork("172.25.123.0/24"), mask_bits=24) self.addCleanup(self.subnets_client.delete_subnet, subnet['id']) with self.rbac_utils.override_role(self): self.subnets_client.show_subnet(self.subnet['id']) @utils.requires_ext(extension='segment', service='network') @decorators.idempotent_id('c02618e7-bb20-1a3b-83c8-6eec2af08753') @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="neutron", rule="create_subnet:segment_id") def test_create_subnet_with_segment_id(self): """Create subnet with segment_id. RBAC test for the neutron "create_subnet:segment_id" policy """ net = self.create_network() self.addCleanup(self.networks_client.delete_network, net['id']) seg = self.segments_client.create_segment(network_id=net['id'], network_type="gre", segmentation_id=1234) self.addCleanup( self.segments_client.delete_segment, seg['segment']['id']) with self.rbac_utils.override_role(self): subnet = self.create_subnet( net, segment_id=seg['segment']['id'], cidr=netaddr.IPNetwork("172.25.123.0/24"), mask_bits=24) self.addCleanup(self.subnets_client.delete_subnet, subnet['id'])

commit_message:
Add tests to cover service_types attribute in subnets

'create_subnet:service_types'
'update_subnet:service_types'

https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2002641

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/584601/

added_lines: @decorators.idempotent_id('0481adeb-7465-44d5-543c-35910cc18a6c') @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="neutron", rules=["create_subnet", "create_subnet:service_types"]) def test_create_subnet_with_service_type(self): """Create subnet with service_type. RBAC test for the neutron "create_subnet:service_types" policy """ with self.rbac_utils.override_role(self): self.create_subnet( self.network, service_types=["network:floatingip_agent_gateway"]) @decorators.idempotent_id('f36cd821-aa11-4bd0-b43d-110fc4b553eb') @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="neutron", rules=[ "update_subnet", "update_subnet:service_types"], expected_error_codes=[403, 403]) def test_update_subnet_with_service_type(self): """Update subnet with service_type. RBAC test for the neutron "update_subnet:service_types" policy """ with self.rbac_utils.override_role(self): self.subnets_client.update_subnet( self.subnet['id'], service_types=["network:floatingip_agent_gateway"])

commit_message:
Fix 'use_dynamic_credentials = false' with Neutron extension tests

When running Neutron extension tests and Tempest configured with
'use_dynamic_credentials = false' the user_id and tenant_id are unset
and results in the tests not being executed: "Could not find user: None."

Both user_id and tenant_id are needed in rbac_utils [0].

[0] https://github.com/openstack/patrole/blob/master/patrole_tempest_plugin/rbac_utils.py#L163

Change-Id: I88d0624bc279b004ebe5f721cdef5adf12bd0ed9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/79/676979/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # user_id and tenant_id are lost when calling the clients.Manager user_id = manager.credentials.user_id tenant_id = manager.credentials.tenant_id # Add the user_id and tenant_id back to the the manager.credentials as # this is lost when calling the clients.Manager. This is only seen when # Tempest is configured to 'use_dynamic_credentials = false'. Both # user_id and tenant_id are needed in rbac_utils manager.credentials.user_id = user_id manager.credentials.tenant_id = tenant_id

commit_message:
Fix resource leak from 'test_create_image_from_volume_backed_server'

'test_create_image_from_volume_backed_server' causes two volumes and one
volume snapshot to be leaked:
 - leak from the attached volume
 - leak from a volume that is created using the image in the tempest.conf
 - leak from a volume snapshot that is created from the attached volume

Change-Id: I2c1a1db8215bd054818ec447afdc02815e9994a4

commit_message:
Retrying create_test_server

Zuul jobs fails very often with errors at creating an object,
presumably this can be resolved by retry a call.

Add `retry` function to RbaccUtils class.
Add `retry` config option.
Override the `create_test_server` function to use `retry`.

Change-Id: Ifad316364eaa9ad0d2885a9fbc7a81024d1b13c8
Story: 2004369
Task: 27972
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/29/642829/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_log import log as loggingLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) @classmethod def retry(cls, func, **kwargs): for i in range(5): try: return func(**kwargs) except Exception as e: LOG.exception("Retry #%d out of %d function '%s'. " "Exception: %s", i + 1, 5, func.__name__, e) @classmethod def create_test_server(cls, **kwargs): return cls.retry(super(BaseV2ComputeRbacTest, cls).create_test_server, **kwargs)

Currently, Patrole supports reading custom JSON policy files, but
not YAML files, the standard policy file extension since Ocata [0].

This commit adds support for Patrole to read YAML policy files in
addition to JSON policy files. The option ``custom_policy_files`` was
changed so that each policy path included must match the following
regular expression:

    r'^[^%]*%s[^%]*\.(json|yaml|yml)$'

This supports the following types of paths, for example:

    * /foo/bar/service/policy.json
    * /foo/bar/service/policy.yaml
    * /foo/bar/service/policy.yml
    * /foo/service.json
    * /foo/service.yaml
    * /foo/service.yml

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/ocata/config-reference/policy-yaml-file.html

Change-Id: I81f1c721da441b4e5da9ae31042aabe7a9e3de45

commit_message:
Add support for reading custom YAML policy files

Currently, Patrole supports reading custom JSON policy files, but
not YAML files, the standard policy file extension since Ocata [0].

This commit adds support for Patrole to read YAML policy files in
addition to JSON policy files. The option ``custom_policy_files`` was
changed so that each policy path included must match the following
regular expression:

    r'^[^%]*%s[^%]*\.(json|yaml|yml)$'

This supports the following types of paths, for example:

    * /foo/bar/service/policy.json
    * /foo/bar/service/policy.yaml
    * /foo/bar/service/policy.yml
    * /foo/service.json
    * /foo/service.yaml
    * /foo/service.yml

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/ocata/config-reference/policy-yaml-file.html

Change-Id: I81f1c721da441b4e5da9ae31042aabe7a9e3de45
Closes-Bug: #1710965

Else if the file extension is .json attempt to # parse the JSON data. if file_ext in supported_extensions[1:]: file_policy_data = yaml.safe_load(temp_file_data) elif file_ext == supported_extensions[0]: file_policy_data = json.loads(temp_file_data) except (IOError, ValueError, yaml.YAMLError) as e: msg += ( "%s file must be valid YAML or JSON file and end " "in a supported extension: %s." % ( file_ext[1:].upper() if file_ext else 'Unknown', supported_extensions)) LOG.error(msg)

subject: Restore credentials after test termination with pre-prov creds
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-01 04:38:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/patrole/commit/25dee355ab0dea502b70734ed75ffff26695b887', 'message': '[WIP] Restore credentials after test termination with pre-prov creds

Currently, Patrole switches the role for the primary Tempest creds
in order to do RBAC testing validation. This is a harmless act
when using dynamic credentials, as they are deleted after test
execution anyway.

However, when using pre-provisioned credentials, this means that the
roles for the set of credentials included in the accounts.yaml file
is permanently changed -- even after test execution. The credentials
in the accounts.yaml acquire the test role defined by `[patrole]
rbac_test_role` but lose the original roles before running any
Patrole tests. This means that it is entirely possible that the
roles enumerated in the accounts.yaml may be wrong after test
execution. Thus, Patrole testing can cause the pre-provisioned
credentials to behave unexpectedly when running, for example,
regular Tempest tests using the same credentials.

Because this behavior is undesirable, Patrole should restore any
credentials changed during test execution after test execution
using the `atexit` module which calls the `_restore_credentials`
callback on interpreter termination.

Note that this is not a bulletproof solution because, as the `atexit`
docs mention [0]:

  The functions registered via this module are not called when the
  program is killed by a signal not handled by Python, when a Python
  fatal internal error is detected, or when os._exit() is called.

Under normal circumstances, however, this commit ensures that the
credentials that are modified during test execution are restored
to their original values if pre-provisioned credentials are set up
in tempest.conf.

Note that this behavior can best be confirmed when using one set
of primary/admin creds in the accounts.yaml file and running the
tests serially so that the creds that are modified belong to the
only Member-role creds defined in the accounts.yaml file.

[0] https://docs.python.org/2/library/atexit.html

Change-Id: I669106422a264b6550f5bbfbf16dc2d47f7a71d8
Closes-Bug: #1714413

commit_message:
Restore credentials after test termination with pre-prov creds

Currently, Patrole switches the role for the primary Tempest creds
in order to do RBAC testing validation. This is a harmless act
when using dynamic credentials, as they are deleted after test
execution anyway.

However, when using pre-provisioned credentials, this means that the
roles for the set of credentials included in the accounts.yaml file
is permanently changed -- even after test execution. The credentials
in the accounts.yaml acquire the test role defined by `[patrole]
rbac_test_role` but lose the original roles before running any
Patrole tests. This means that it is entirely possible that the
roles enumerated in the accounts.yaml may be wrong after test
execution. Thus, Patrole testing can cause the pre-provisioned
credentials to behave unexpectedly when running, for example,
regular Tempest tests using the same credentials.

Because this behavior is undesirable, Patrole should restore any
credentials changed during test execution after test execution
using the `atexit` module which calls the `_restore_credentials`
callback on interpreter termination.

Note that this is not a bulletproof solution because, as the `atexit`
docs mention [0]:

  The functions registered via this module are not called when the
  program is killed by a signal not handled by Python, when a Python
  fatal internal error is detected, or when os._exit() is called.

Under normal circumstances, however, this commit ensures that the
credentials that are modified during test execution are restored
to their original values if pre-provisioned credentials are set up
in tempest.conf.

Note that this behavior can best be confirmed when using one set
of primary/admin creds in the accounts.yaml file and running the
tests serially so that the creds that are modified belong to the
only Member-role creds defined in the accounts.yaml file.

[0] https://docs.python.org/2/library/atexit.html

Change-Id: I669106422a264b6550f5bbfbf16dc2d47f7a71d8
Closes-Bug: #1714413
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/85/499885/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import atexit_ORIGINAL_ROLES = {} def _get_admin_roles_client(test_obj=None): # Get admin roles client for switching roles. The credentials used to # instantiate the manager are the default Tempest admin credentials in # `[auth]` config group. This function is also called by `atexit` via # `_restore_credentials`, so fallback to `auth_version` in config since the # `test_obj` will not be available during interpreter termination. identity_version = (test_obj.get_identity_version() if test_obj else CONF.identity.auth_version) admin_mgr = clients.Manager( credentials.get_configured_admin_credentials()) if identity_version == 'v3': admin_roles_client = admin_mgr.roles_v3_client else: admin_roles_client = admin_mgr.roles_client return admin_roles_client def _restore_credentials(): # Role switching is used by `RbacUtils` to switch credentials for # `os_primary`. With dynamic credentials, it does not matter if the creds # aren't restored to their original values as dynamic creds are destroyed # anyway. But with pre-provisioned credentials, the creds should be # restored to their original values following test termination. admin_roles_client = _get_admin_roles_client() for (project_id, user_id), orig_role_ids in _ORIGINAL_ROLES.items(): current_roles = admin_roles_client.list_user_roles_on_project( project_id, user_id)['roles'] current_role_ids = [role['id'] for role in current_roles] for role_id in current_role_ids: admin_roles_client.delete_role_from_user_on_project( project_id, user_id, role_id) for role_id in orig_role_ids: admin_roles_client.create_user_role_on_project( project_id, user_id, role_id) def __init__(self, test_obj): """Constructor for ``RbacUtils``. :param test_obj: An instance of `tempest.test.BaseTestCase`. # Intialize the admin roles_client to perform role switching. self.admin_roles_client = _get_admin_roles_client(test_obj) self.switch_role(test_obj, toggle_rbac_role=False) if (self.project_id, self.user_id) not in _ORIGINAL_ROLES: _ORIGINAL_ROLES.setdefault((self.project_id, self.user_id), role_ids) def _get_roles_by_name(self): if not all([admin_role_id, rbac_role_id]): msg = ("Roles defined by `[patrole] rbac_test_role` and " "`[identity] admin_role` must be defined in the system.") def switch_role(self, test_obj, toggle_rbac_role=False): """Switch the role used by `os_primary` Tempest credentials. Switch the role used by `os_primary` credentials to: * admin if `toggle_rbac_role` is False * `CONF.patrole.rbac_test_role` if `toggle_rbac_role` is True :param test_obj: test object of type tempest.lib.base.BaseTestCase :param toggle_rbac_role: role to switch `os_primary` Tempest creds to """ self.user_id = test_obj.os_primary.credentials.user_id self.project_id = test_obj.os_primary.credentials.tenant_id self.token = test_obj.os_primary.auth_provider.get_token() LOG.debug('Switching role to: %s.', toggle_rbac_role) role_already_present = False try: if not all([self.admin_role_id, self.rbac_role_id]): self._get_roles_by_name() self._validate_switch_role(test_obj, toggle_rbac_role) target_role = ( self.rbac_role_id if toggle_rbac_role else self.admin_role_id) role_already_present = self._list_and_clear_user_roles_on_project( target_role) # Do not switch roles if `target_role` already exists. if not role_already_present: self._create_user_role_on_project(target_role) except Exception as exp: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.exception(exp) finally: test_obj.os_primary.auth_provider.clear_auth() # Fernet tokens are not subsecond aware so sleep to ensure we are # passing the second boundary before attempting to authenticate. # Only sleep if a token revocation occurred as a result of role # switching. This will optimize test runtime in the case where # ``[identity] admin_role`` == ``[rbac] rbac_test_role``. if not role_already_present: time.sleep(1) test_obj.os_primary.auth_provider.set_auth() # Only restore the credentials if using pre-provisioned credentials following # test termination. if CONF.auth.test_accounts_file: atexit.register(_restore_credentials)
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, test_obj): """Constructor for ``RbacUtils``. :param test_obj: An instance of `tempest.test.BaseTestCase`. """ # Intialize the admin roles_client to perform role switching. admin_mgr = clients.Manager( credentials.get_configured_admin_credentials()) if test_obj.get_identity_version() == 'v3': admin_roles_client = admin_mgr.roles_v3_client else: admin_roles_client = admin_mgr.roles_client self.admin_roles_client = admin_roles_client self.switch_role(test_obj, toggle_rbac_role=False) def switch_role(self, test_obj, toggle_rbac_role=False): """Switch the role used by `os_primary` Tempest credentials. This will optimize test runtime in the case where # ``[identity] admin_role`` == ``[rbac] rbac_test_role``. if not role_already_present: time.sleep(1) test_obj.os_primary.auth_provider.set_auth() def _get_roles_by_name(self): available_roles = self.admin_roles_client.list_roles() admin_role_id = rbac_role_id = None for role in available_roles['roles']: if role['name'] == CONF.patrole.rbac_test_role: rbac_role_id = role['id'] if role['name'] == CONF.identity.admin_role: admin_role_id = role['id'] if not all([admin_role_id, rbac_role_id]): msg = ("Roles defined by `[patrole] rbac_test_role` and " "`[identity] admin_role` must be defined in the system.") raise rbac_exceptions.RbacResourceSetupFailed(msg) self.admin_role_id = admin_role_id self.rbac_role_id = rbac_role_id def _get_roles(self): if not admin_role_id or not rbac_role_id: msg = "Role with name 'admin' does not exist in the system."\ if not admin_role_id else "Role defined by rbac_test_role "\ "does not exist in the system."

commit_message:
Remove users with system scope from roles dict

For users with system scope keystone could return empty endpoints
in catalog in response to token issue request. Catalog content
is used in tests, for example in tempest.api.volume.admin.
test_volume_quotas_negative.VolumeQuotasNegativeTestJSON. If we use
tempest static creds and system scoped creds are picked up for test
mentioned above it will lead to error. Proposed fix remove accounts
with system scope frome roles part of hash_dict.

Closes-Bug: 2004261
Change-Id: I0ab5698c86d61ccbf959f3a71025794bcb51ed0e

commit_message:
Rename setup-mtu-t1 argument because it is misleading

setup-mtu-t1 argument name is misleading as it suggest that
it will do something with the MTU value, but it really just reduces
DHCP agent t1 timer. The fact that this commnad will have a side
effect of getting a new MTU value from DHCP should not be part
of the argument name. This is based on customer's feedback.
I am keeping backward compatibility for setup-mtu-t1 argument
in order not to break any existing tools that might depend on it.

Change-Id: I939b21fa998c80cf921efeae3e8fa8c2b4ef4f50
(cherry picked from commit c2fb0b16b66b69c48a8e6d9d304f0efe851d7566)

subject: nova-scheduler: Encourage weighers to spread
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-10 22:03:08.000000000', 'files': ['nova/scheduler/weights/cpu.py', 'nova/scheduler/weights/ram.py', 'nova/scheduler/weights/disk.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1a5c0bad095392a0654037c5f6bd1d22aceda9e6', 'message': 'nova-scheduler: Encourage weighers to spread

Many of the resource weighers in Nova (CPU, disk, RAM)
encourage "stacking" of allocations instead of "spreading"
in heterogeneous environments.

That is to say, the weighers preferentially keep assigning
greater weights to the hypervisors with most free resources
by absolute value. In extreme cases, this result in some
some hypervisors going into logical resource overcommit
before other hypervisors have a single allocation assigned
to them.

To encourage spreading in heterogeneous environments,
resource weighing (and normalization) really needs to occur
with respect to the utilization of each host as a percent
value. Hence this commit, which changes the behavior of the
impacted weighers accordingly.

Signed-off-by: Tyler Stachecki <tstachecki@bloomberg.net>
Change-Id: I9e4973e2b88af9fe29378878e00873ab4004adcc
Closes-Bug: 2011127
'}]
commit_message:
nova-scheduler: Encourage weighers to spread

Many of the resource weighers in Nova (CPU, disk, RAM)
encourage "stacking" of allocations instead of "spreading"
in heterogeneous environments.

That is to say, the weighers preferentially keep assigning
greater weights to the hypervisors with most free resources
by absolute value. In extreme cases, this result in some
some hypervisors going into logical resource overcommit
before other hypervisors have a single allocation assigned
to them.

To encourage spreading in heterogeneous environments,
resource weighing (and normalization) really needs to occur
with respect to the utilization of each host as a percent
value. Hence this commit, which changes the behavior of the
impacted weighers accordingly.

Signed-off-by: Tyler Stachecki <tstachecki@bloomberg.net>
Change-Id: I9e4973e2b88af9fe29378878e00873ab4004adcc
Closes-Bug: 2011127
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/89/876289/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix ceph pool creation failure

During `openstack overcloud deploy`, ceph create pool operation
fails on RHSCSv6 as the podman command generated by 'ceph_pool'
ansible module has the volume argument as /etc/ceph.

This patch ensures to use the '/var/lib/ceph/$FSID/config/'
in the podman command generated by all the ansible moduels.

Even the 'tripleo_cephadm_ceph_cli' is updated to use the
new path.

Resolves: rhbz#2172582
Change-Id: I570ce859c3033d0f8cc36064f851419fca1a9d66
(cherry picked from commit 0c3a54a6efa9c0e320e949e251f25f72f5a489de)

commit_message:
[OVN] Method ``get_port_qos`` should always return 2 values

The method ``neutron.agent.ovn.agent.ovsdb.get_port_qos`` should
always return 2 values, even when the LSP is not present. This
patch:
* fixes the output, returning 2 values
* catches the exception raised when the LSP is not present in the
  OVN NB database
* returns the default max_kbps and min_kbps values (0, 0).

Closes-Bug: #2009804
Change-Id: I03ea78fcc5825e35c07dda1aa790769aa918dd8a
(cherry picked from commit bffa642b351f7fc3bb5cfb7a1bb2a3499c4b4506)

subject: Revert "Run virtqemud with umask 0027"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-02-21 13:38:43.000000000', 'files': ['deployment/nova/nova-modular-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/1002a67e6d3298ffaa50cbb17391dda27a6f3fce', 'message': 'Revert "Run virtqemud with umask 0027"

This reverts commit 7bba86fc582b6d599117be06c23d0a3d91332cfd.

Reason for revert: Fix regression for virtqemud is started with umask of 0027 which then gets in the way libvirt sets up hugepages. In this particular case, libvirtd/virtqemud creates $hugetlbfs/libvirt/qemu/ (/dev/hugepages/libvirt/qemu/ in this case) which is meant as top level directory, a base where individual, per-guest directories are then created. Now, the top level directory is owned by root:root (so that nobody else can modify its perms) but we also want it to be accessible by other processes (mind you, we don't need to list the directory (o+r), we need to be able to access subdirs (o+x)).

Setting such restrictive umask for a process that is supposed to prepare environment for other users (QEMU runs under qemu:qemu) was a bad choice because of that, hence this revert

Change-Id: I75897fbaf7d9415178bc267c848b83775a384814
Related: rhbz#2166979
(cherry picked from commit 88ab470d82b4efcaa1582474d4b5bc087f437cd9)
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Run virtqemud with umask 0027"

This reverts commit 7bba86fc582b6d599117be06c23d0a3d91332cfd.

Reason for revert: Fix regression for virtqemud is started with umask of 0027 which then gets in the way libvirt sets up hugepages. In this particular case, libvirtd/virtqemud creates $hugetlbfs/libvirt/qemu/ (/dev/hugepages/libvirt/qemu/ in this case) which is meant as top level directory, a base where individual, per-guest directories are then created. Now, the top level directory is owned by root:root (so that nobody else can modify its perms) but we also want it to be accessible by other processes (mind you, we don't need to list the directory (o+r), we need to be able to access subdirs (o+x)).

Setting such restrictive umask for a process that is supposed to prepare environment for other users (QEMU runs under qemu:qemu) was a bad choice because of that, hence this revert

Change-Id: I75897fbaf7d9415178bc267c848b83775a384814
Related: rhbz#2166979
(cherry picked from commit 88ab470d82b4efcaa1582474d4b5bc087f437cd9)

commit_message:
Add Antelope support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to antelope
* align testing with antelope
* add new antelope bundles
* add antelope bundles to tests.yaml
* add antelope tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases

Change-Id: I733a6c785ef76b602a6d4950403abbd31da6a03b

commit_message:
Rename setup-mtu-t1 argument because it is misleading

setup-mtu-t1 argument name is misleading as it suggest that
it will do something with the MTU value, but it really just reduces
DHCP agent t1 timer. The fact that this commnad will have a side
effect of getting a new MTU value from DHCP should not be part
of the argument name. This is based on customer's feedback.
I am keeping backward compatibility for setup-mtu-t1 argument
in order not to break any existing tools that might depend on it.

Change-Id: I939b21fa998c80cf921efeae3e8fa8c2b4ef4f50
(cherry picked from commit c2fb0b16b66b69c48a8e6d9d304f0efe851d7566)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/26/876926/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: echo "Please review the file before running the next command - setup-mtu-t1"setup_mtu_t1() { Step 2 -> ovn_migration.sh setup-mtu-t1 setup-mtu-t1) setup_mtu_t1

commit_message:
Add Antelope support

* Add new antelope bundles
* Drop focal and kinetic bundles
* Drop jammy-yoga bundle
* Use generic job templates in osci.yaml
* Update build-on and run-on bases
* Amend path to built charm
* Add .zuul.yaml
* Add .gitreview file
* passenv OS_* and TEST_* env variables
* Update allowlist_externals

Change-Id: Ib2b1713198cc0daaff81cf7738e4623c5d965a46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ironic-dashboard refs/changes/02/877102/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: bash -c "if [ ! -f ./*.charm ]; then echo 'Charm does not exist. Run tox -e build'; exit 1; fi"
deleted_lines: bash -c "if [ ! -f ../*.charm ]; then echo 'Charm does not exist. Run tox -e build'; exit 1; fi"

commit_message:
Add Antelope support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to antelope
* align testing with antelope
* add new antelope bundles
* add antelope bundles to tests.yaml
* add antelope tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases

Change-Id: I698b89d2c4dfff7b667a810a42adda665773a5ce

commit_message:
Add Antelope support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to antelope
* align testing with antelope

* add antelope bundles to tests.yaml
* add antelope tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases

commit_message:
Restructure the inspector module in preparation for its expansion

Converts ironic.drivers.modules.inspector into a package with
two subpackages: client and interface, the latter containing most
of the current content.

Change-Id: Idbfd275c60a873e3de2e0a34db793619f8c99d85

Add a non-voting metal3 CI job

We'll use only one node as we're limited in resources but that
should suffice for a basic test.

commit_message:
[FIPS] Install nettle-3.8-3.el9 in tcib base container

This patch adds installation of nettle-3.8-3.el9 to replace the rhel-9.0
version of the package, since 'dnf udpate' doesn't replace it.
The rhel-9.0 version of this package fails when running under FIPS.
When we get a new version o nettle in centos mirrors, the 'dnf update'
shall install a new version of the package and the workaround can be
remove.
We can't add a condition to install only when fips is enabled, since
build containers job doesn't run under fips enabled mode.

Related-Bug: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2154924
Related-Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1984237
Change-Id: I4817edd840043a93e23612227910bd7e4fce85c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/51/876751/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO: Temporary pinning nettle to 3.8-3.el9, so it can be reinstalled from centos-9 repos. # nettle-3.8-3 is already installed in ubi9 image, but it conflicts with newer versions on gnutls # installed from centos-9 repos. This workaround can be reverted once ubi9.2 is released, which # should contain a newer version of gnutls with fixes to run under FIPS mode. # See: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2154924 and # https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1984237 - run: >- if [ '{{ tcib_release }}' == '9' ];then dnf -y install nettle-3.8-3.el9; fi

subject: Limit rax-ord launch concurrency and don't retry
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-10 17:53:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/bcb9332507d6c5b700b91358ecbc0cf65592ebd9', 'message': 'Further increase rax-ord launch timeout no retries

This region seems to take a very long time to launch nodes when we
have a burst of requests for them, like a thundering herd sort of
behavior causing launch times to increase substantially. We have a
lot of capacity in this region though, so want to boot as many
instances as we can here. In order to balance that, increase the
timeout but don't retry launch failures so that we won't ever lock a
request for multiples of the new timeout.

Also try to further mitigate the thundering herd by significantly
increasing the API "rate" (really delay) to one call per second.

Change-Id: I179ab22df37b2f996288820074ec69b8e0a202a5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2023-03-10 18:09:44.000000000', 'files': ['nodepool/nl01.opendev.org.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/d0481326bf799eb2921e3ae073172d49aca41591', 'message': "Limit rax-ord launch concurrency and don't retry

have a burst of requests for them, like a thundering herd sort of
behavior causing launch times to increase substantially. We have a
lot of capacity in this region though, so want to boot as many
instances as we can here. Attempt to reduce the effect by limiting
the number of instances nodepool will launch at the same time.

Also, mitigate the higher timeout for this provider by not retrying

Change-Id: I179ab22df37b2f996288820074ec69b8e0a202a5
"}]
commit_message:
Limit rax-ord launch concurrency and don't retry

This region seems to take a very long time to launch nodes when we
have a burst of requests for them, like a thundering herd sort of
behavior causing launch times to increase substantially. We have a
lot of capacity in this region though, so want to boot as many
instances as we can here. Attempt to reduce the effect by limiting
the number of instances nodepool will launch at the same time.

Also, mitigate the higher timeout for this provider by not retrying
launch failures, so that we won't ever lock a request for multiples
of the timeout.

Change-Id: I179ab22df37b2f996288820074ec69b8e0a202a5

commit_message:
Add Antelope support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to antelope
* align testing with antelope
* add new antelope bundles
* add antelope bundles to tests.yaml
* add antelope tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases

Change-Id: I884e0f8fa0602fb9b9ab79157619f4cd18191b79

added_lines: def safe_to_destroy(osd_id, timeout=300): ret = subprocess.call([ 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'safe-to-destroy', osd_id ], timeout=timeout)def safe_to_stop(osd_id, timeout=300): ret = subprocess.call([ 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'ok-to-stop', osd_id ], timeout=timeout)def reweight_osd(osd_id, timeout=300): subprocess.check_call([ 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'crush', 'reweight', osd_id, '0' ], timeout=timeout) def destroy(osd_id, purge=False, timeout=300): subprocess.check_call([ 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'purge' if purge else 'destroy', osd_id, '--yes-i-really-mean-it' ], timeout=timeout)
deleted_lines: def safe_to_destroy(osd_id): ret = subprocess.call(['ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'safe-to-destroy', osd_id])def safe_to_stop(osd_id): ret = subprocess.call(['ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'ok-to-stop', osd_id])def reweight_osd(osd_id): subprocess.check_call(['ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'crush', 'reweight', osd_id, '0']) def destroy(osd_id, purge=False): subprocess.check_call(['ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'purge' if purge else 'destroy', osd_id, '--yes-i-really-mean-it'])

The method ``neutron.agent.ovn.agent.ovsdb.get_port_qos`` should
always return 2 values, even when the LSP is not present. This
patch:
* fixes the output, returning 2 values
* catches the exception raised when the LSP is not present in the
  OVN NB database
* returns the default max_kbps and min_kbps values (0, 0).

Change-Id: I03ea78fcc5825e35c07dda1aa790769aa918dd8a

commit_message:
[OVN] Method ``get_port_qos`` should always return 2 values

The method ``neutron.agent.ovn.agent.ovsdb.get_port_qos`` should
always return 2 values, even when the LSP is not present. This
patch:
* fixes the output, returning 2 values
* catches the exception raised when the LSP is not present in the
  OVN NB database
* returns the default max_kbps and min_kbps values (0, 0).

Closes-Bug: #2009804
Change-Id: I03ea78fcc5825e35c07dda1aa790769aa918dd8a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/45/876945/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Glance: Include the required glance::limit class for unified quotas

Including glance::limit for enabling unified quotas in glance
and glance::limit class requires a glance endpoint_id & password,
so adding thses 2 parameters in hieradata with their default value
'None'.

Change-Id: Ic3d2dc927f4ce2b118ee98811db74e4ac8dfb96a

commit_message:
Use standalone bootstrap playbook from tripleo-ansible

Update tripleo-heat-templates to use the bootstrap playbook from
tripleo-ansible. Removes tasks that are not refactored into the
playbook.

Depends-On: Ie36cc178c7b41a1f8988f3ab5968bc310f6f5455
Change-Id: I0e2a00e54f23c96bef8b92f571b482362028a701
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Create ephemeral heat.conf for rabbitmq/mysql config

Instead of relying on using the hiera CLI (which is now deprecated) from
tripleoclient, create a heat.conf for use with ephemeral Heat that sets
the needed configs for the rabbitmq transport_url and the mysql database
connection.

Change-Id: I12b03d9099c9434f08d42cc291f6282fc4496dbf
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/32/863432/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Create heat.conf for ephemeral Heat block when: - step|int == 1 - not ansible_check_mode|bool become: true vars: heat_ephemeral_config_dir: /var/lib/config-data/ansible-generated/heat-ephemeral/etc/heat block: - name: Create {{ heat_ephemeral_config_dir }} file: path: "{{ heat_ephemeral_config_dir }}" state: directory recurse: true mode: '0755' - name: Create heat.conf for ephemeral Heat copy: dest: "{{ heat_ephemeral_config_dir }}/heat.conf" mode: '0666' content: | [DEFAULT] transport_url="rabbit://{{ service_configs['rabbitmq::default_user'] }}:{{ service_configs['rabbitmq::default_pass'] }}@{{ fqdn_ctlplane }}:{{ service_configs['rabbitmq::port'] }}/?ssl=0" [database] connection="mysql+pymysql://heat:heat@{{ ctlplane_ip | ipwrap }}/heat?read_default_file=/etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf&read_default_group=tripleo"

commit_message:
Add a spaces concepts page

Add a page that provides a conceptual overview of how
network spaces are applied in the context of Charmed
OpenStack.

Change-Id: I7c103e8b249bdcff1c2db9a43d5f776ca4007ee7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-guide refs/changes/74/874974/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================================== Network Spaces and Charmed OpenStack ==================================== Overview -------- This document provides a conceptual overview of the role that Juju network spaces play in the deployment and management of Charmed OpenStack. A network space is a Juju object that abstracts away the OSI L3 layer. A space is created on the backing cloud to represent one or more subnets. The purpose of a space is to allow for user-defined network traffic segmentation, which can have various uses (e.g. traffic isolation as a security measure). Note: See the Juju documentation to fully explore spaces themselves. Spaces support -------------- For Charmed OpenStack, the recommended Juju backing cloud is MAAS. Spaces can be created and configured within MAAS (by associating them with VLANs and subnets) and the Juju operator can immediately make use of them when deploying or configuring OpenStack applications. GRAPHIC of MAAS web UI Bindings -------- A space is associated with an application's traffic type via the latter's corresponding "endpoint". This association is known as a "binding". This specific traffic flow is established once the endpoint is "integrated" with another application's endpoint (the juju integrate command). .. note:: Integration is the process of connecting compatible endpoints between two applications. Endpoints are discerned from a charm's metadata.yaml file. Extra bindings ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Juju has the notion of an "extra binding". Like a normal binding, an extra binding requests, via spaces, that a machine be provisioned with network connectivity to specific subnets. The intention is that the charm that supports the binding will then configure its payload service, whose consumer may be external to Juju, to listen on a certain IP address(es). This type of binding is not dependent upon an integration with another application's endpoint. .. note:: Extra bindings are explicitly declared in a charm's metadata.yaml file. Default space ------------- A default value for spaces can be set at the model level and at the application level. A model's default space is defined with the juju model-config command. If left unset, the (default) value is 'alpha'. .. code-block:: none juju model-config -m <model> default-space=<space> .. note:: The juju model-default command can be used to affect all future models. A space is defined at the application level at deploy time (juju deploy). This becomes the application's de facto default space. That is, any scale out operation (juju add-unit) will inherit this value and any further integrations for the application will also use this value. .. note:: It has been reported that the default space at the model level does not work for LXD containers. This issue is being tracked in LP #1883164. Initial application unit ------------------------ When an application's initial unit is deployed, if the underlying subnet resides within a space then a binding must be formed by referencing a space. This is because the unit must be in a subnet in order to be assigned an IP address. The reference can be done explicitly at deploy time or implicitly via a model default. .. code-block:: none juju deploy --bind <space> <charm> Spaces as a constraint ---------------------- With the MAAS provider (backing cloud) the deployment of the initial unit can refer to a space as a Juju constraint. This simply ensures that the resulting machine has a network interface on a certain subnet(s). It is not used by the charm to implement any network functionality, as does a normal or extra binding: .. code-block:: none juju deploy --constraints spaces=<space> <charm> Such a constraint can be used in combination with a binding (using different space values naturally): .. code-block:: none juju deploy --constraints spaces=<space-1> --bind <space-2> <charm> LXD containers -------------- There is a subtle distinction between applying space constraints to LXD containers as opposed to bare metal or KVM-based MAAS nodes. For the latter types, a constraint represents a network criterion, whereas for dynamically-provisioned containers, a constraint acts as a request to add network connectivity. The underlying host however must be able to satisfy that request in terms of its own network connectivity. Subordinate applications ------------------------ A subordinate application always runs alongside a principal application and is only actually deployed when an integration is formed with its principal. Owing to this behaviour, the bindings of a subordinate application must be a subset of the bindings of the principal application. Multi-subnet spaces and routing ------------------------------- A binding (or extra binding) should be seen as a request to allocate traffic to certain subnets if possible, and not as a mechanism that alters or verifies routing at the L3 level. In the case of a multi-subnet space, this implies that network connectivity among those subnets must exist externally to Juju. Here are two key scenarios to watch out for when a multi-subnet space is desired: * multi-unit applications * any two integrated applications In each of the above scenarios, inter-subnet routing must be configured in advance to allow for the application units to reach one another. In other words, all subnets/VLANs within the same space are assumed to have unrestricted traffic. It should also be noted that an integration formed between two applications is not indicative of successful routing. Working with integrations and bindings -------------------------------------- This section will apply the concepts with an example scenario: that of deploying Vault and connecting it to the cloud database as in this section of the Deploy Guide. Here however, we will highlight how integrations and bindings are formed. The metadata.yaml file ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The pertinent contents of the metadata.yaml file for the vault and mysql-router charms will be shown. This consists of the following YAML keys: * provides * requires * extra-bindings This gives us: The vault charm: .. code-block:: yaml series: bionic applications: trilio-wlm: charm: ch:trilio-wlm Okay .. code-block:: yaml extra-bindings: access: external: provides: nrpe-external-master: interface: nrpe-external-master scope:container secrets: interface: vault-kv certificates: interface: tls-certificates requires: db: interface: pgsql shared-db: interface: mysql-shared etcd: interface: etcd ha: interface: hacluster scope: container lb-provider: interface: loadbalancer limit: 1 The mysql-router charm: .. code-block:: console provides: shared-db: interface: mysql-shared scope: container requires: juju-info: interface: juju-info scope: container db-router: interface: mysql-router Manual commands ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Some manual commands are included here that show how to achieve the objective. It is assumed that: * there are two spaces available to the MAAS cluster ('public-space' and 'access-space') * a default space is not configured at the model level * a cloud database is pre-existing (the mysql-innodb-cluster application) To deploy the vault application and set its default space to 'public-space': .. code-block:: none juju deploy --bind public-space --to lxd:3 --channel 1.8/stable vault To deploy the mysql-router application and integrate it with the cloud database: .. code-block:: none juju deploy --channel 8.0/stable mysql-router vault-mysql-router juju integrate vault-mysql-router:db-router mysql-innodb-cluster:db-router To integrate the shared-db endpoint of the vault application with the shared-db endpoint of the vault-mysql-router application: .. code-block:: none juju integrate vault-mysql-router:shared-db vault:shared-db The shared-db endpoint traffic will now be confined to space 'public-space'. .. note:: Regardless of the common name of the two endpoints, it is technically the common interface name of mysql-shared that makes the above integration possible. To form a binding between the access endpoint and the 'access-space' space: .. code-block:: none juju bind vault access=access-space An integration is not necessary for the access endpoint due to it being associated with an extra binding. The bundle method ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The entire example deployment can be expressed in the following bundle file, say vault-to-database.yaml: .. code-block:: console machines: '3': applications: vault-mysql-router: charm: ch:mysql-router channel: 8.0/stable vault: charm: ch:vault channel: 1.8/stable num_units: 1 bindings: "": public-space access: access-space to: - lxd:3 relations: - - vault-mysql-router:db-router - mysql-innodb-cluster:db-router - - vault:shared-db - vault-mysql-router:shared-db The pair of double quotation marks denotes the default space for an application. To deploy: .. code-block:: none juju deploy ./vault-to-database.yaml

commit_message:
Restore quincy/edge channel in test bundles

The bundles were temporarily switched to use quincy/stable
to work around the related bug. This changes ensures
the channels are restored to quincy/edge.

Change-Id: I04e2796779640e5004f2e1679ee9a3113eab1bb8
Related-Bug: #1995086

commit_message:
Allow nebulous-project-config-core to submit changes

This is necessary to make the nebulous tenant self-sustaining by
allowing this group to merge untested/failing changes in case of
a serious misconfiguration not solvable otherwise.

Change-Id: Ieb5c83b3e94b16f4d9c1602f7a1d8da27d9e5543

commit_message:
Expose ovn lb on provider network if tenant network is disabled

The logic to expose the ovn lb on the provider network was
relying on the information about the tenant networks connected to
the cr-lrp, that is only filled in when tenant networks are also
exposed. This patch is changing that so that this loadbalancers
are exposed even if the tenant networks are not.

Change-Id: I297af3b87b9683724977c279d0f5f5157abe2672

commit_message:
ovs: fix regression when vlan mapping is not already registered

Bug introduced by Ic3c147136549b17aea0fe78e930a41a5b33ab9d8, when a
VLAN mapping is not registered during a call to
update_network_segement, the function should return None.

Closes-Bug: #2009215
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@industrialdiscipline.com>
Change-Id: I91f8e8bd18d9956216e5715c658dfb408a2cbf07
(cherry picked from commit cf96bd8bdf9751c54ba8d47569e4a1269fc61e9e)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I487f7bb126b782925a61b9eb144214f78baf8cc0

commit_message:
Drop empty elements from constraint/requirement files

We should filter out empty elements from lists that are provided as
input to the role, to ensure idempotence of build constraints and
requirements file as a result.

Additionally to that we should ensure to control jinja whitespaces
not to add extra new lines to the end of files.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/872896
Change-Id: Ide47712f775c91d90b749bc8e4d8f87c5bd658f2
Closes-Bug: #2004546
(cherry picked from commit 2a25337b9844b4b8a90420e864ee38e8168ce586)

subject: test_provision: don't assert provision_node call order
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-09 20:39:36.000000000', 'files': ['metalsmith/test/test_metalsmith_instances.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith/commit/073bfb1978f37e073b86b786ce69cda8c2a58528', 'message': "test_provision: don't assert provision_node call order

provision_node is called from thread pool workers so the call order is
not deterministic. This causes py38 job failures sometimes.

This change asserts that the expected calls are occuring, but not
their order.

Change-Id: Id9f870e35dc9c92f0456d85c087514fb53053b76
(cherry picked from commit 43eec5a109888791ea395b2bab201106cbcdfff1)
"}]
commit_message:
test_provision: don't assert provision_node call order

provision_node is called from thread pool workers so the call order is
not deterministic. This causes py38 job failures sometimes.

This change asserts that the expected calls are occuring, but not
their order.

Change-Id: Id9f870e35dc9c92f0456d85c087514fb53053b76
(cherry picked from commit 43eec5a109888791ea395b2bab201106cbcdfff1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith refs/changes/42/877042/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Pin tox < 4 (pacific)

This patchset works around issues with versions of tox > 4

Change-Id: I4d3beb38d35db73fecb35593dcfe943dae683dd1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-osd refs/changes/01/871801/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # NOTES: # * We avoid the new dependency resolver by pinning pip < 20.3, see # https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/9187 # * Pinning dependencies requires tox >= 3.2.0, see # https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-requires # * It is also necessary to pin virtualenv as a newer virtualenv would still # lead to fetching the latest pip in the func* tox targets, see # https://stackoverflow.com/a/38133283 pip < 20.3 virtualenv < 20.0 setuptools < 50.0.0 charm-tools==2.8.3

commit_message:
Use the SDK for server show

Use the SDK for the server show command. This change modifies a helper
function that is used by server show as well as other commands that
print information about an individual server. The helper still uses
novaclient APIs when additional OpenStack requests are needed since some
of its callers are still using the nova client.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/864340
Change-Id: Ic253184ee5f911ec2052419d328260dc4664b273

added_lines: compute_client = self.app.client_manager.sdk_connection.compute # Find by name or ID, then get the full details of the server server = compute_client.find_server( parsed_args.server, ignore_missing=False) server = compute_client.get_server(server) data = compute_client.get_server_diagnostics(server) if not sdk_utils.supports_microversion(compute_client, '2.78'): topology = server.fetch_topology(compute_client) # TODO(dannosliwcd): Replace with SDK client after all callers of # _prep_server_detail() are using the SDK. self.app.client_manager.compute, self.app.client_manager.image, server,
deleted_lines: compute_client = self.app.client_manager.compute server = utils.find_resource( compute_client.servers, parsed_args.server) (resp, data) = server.diagnostics() if not resp.status_code == 200: self.app.stderr.write(_( "Error retrieving diagnostics data\n" )) return ({}, {}) if compute_client.api_version < api_versions.APIVersion('2.78'): topology = server.topology() compute_client, self.app.client_manager.image, server,

commit_message:
Fix unit tests with python-novaclient 18.3.0

python-novaclient 18.3.0 replaced usage of kwargs by explicit arguments
and that broke some assertions of arguments.

story: 2010638
task: 47613
Change-Id: I039d1e672611b7b523ce61df072c60d161851eed
(cherry picked from commit 513dfd116e5177cb43a0fb78471ad1992f16210d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/22/876922/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(tkajinam): python-novaclient 18.3.0 removed usage of args/kwargs # and now all arguments are defined. To make the test # independent from the underlying inteface as much as # possible we inspect kwargs and check what we intend # to define in Heat's logic. mock_rebuild.assert_called_once() self.assertEqual((return_server, '2'), mock_rebuild.call_args.args) if 'REBUILD' == policy: self.assertLessEqual( { 'password': password, 'preserve_ephemeral': False, 'meta': {}, 'files': {} }.items(), mock_rebuild.call_args.kwargs.items() ) else: self.assertLessEqual( { 'password': password, 'preserve_ephemeral': True, 'meta': {}, 'files': {} }.items(), mock_rebuild.call_args.kwargs.items() ) # NOTE(tkajinam): python-novaclient 18.3.0 removed usage of args/kwargs # and now all arguments are defined. To make the test # independent from the underlying inteface as much as # possible we inspect kwargs and check what we intend # to define in Heat's logic. mock_rebuild.assert_called_once() self.assertEqual((return_server, '2'), mock_rebuild.call_args.args) self.assertLessEqual( { 'password': None, 'preserve_ephemeral': False, 'meta': {}, 'files': {} }.items(), mock_rebuild.call_args.kwargs.items() )
deleted_lines: if 'REBUILD' == policy: mock_rebuild.assert_called_once_with( return_server, '2', password=password, preserve_ephemeral=False, meta={}, files={}) else: mock_rebuild.assert_called_once_with( return_server, '2', password=password, preserve_ephemeral=True, meta={}, files={}) mock_rebuild.assert_called_once_with( return_server, '2', password=None, preserve_ephemeral=False, meta={}, files={})

Migrate ceph-rbd-mirror to charmhub - octopus

This is the stable/octopus branch of ceph-rbd-mirror. It tests
against bionic-train (nautilus) and focal-ussuri (octopus).

Run tox -e build'; exit 1; fi" tox --version tox -e func-target {posargs}

commit_message:
Pin tox to < 4.0.0

Tox 4.0.0 was recently released and it has several breaking changes.
We pin to < 4.0.0 here. We are planning to move forward only on the
master charm branches.

Tox is also pinned to < 4.0.0 for stable branches in upstream
openstack-zuul-jobs as well as in zosci-config. However, the
requires= section in the charm's tox.ini file ends up installing
tox>4, wiping out the zuul-pinned tox<4 that was already installed
installed. This patch fixes that.

Related-Bug: #2002788
Change-Id: I92bc88c044cc1dd1ca65ae59273d8ff9c20f9812

commit_message:
Fix share network create command with the AZ option

Previously, "share network create" command was trying to look up
the availability-zone provided by the user. However, this is not supported
by the AvailabilityZoneManager.

Drop the AZ lookup if the option is used and pass the user provided value
to the API.

Closes-Bug: 1962288
Change-Id: I3ec926122eed932caebcb31b9afd0f811f1f3c8e

subject: Limit CaptureRegion sizes in format_inspector for VMDK and VHDX
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-02-07 16:49:15.000000000', 'files': ['glance/tests/unit/common/test_format_inspector.py', 'glance/common/format_inspector.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/06a18202ab52c64803f044b8f848ed1c160905d2', 'message': 'Limit CaptureRegion sizes in format_inspector for VMDK and VHDX

VMDK:
When parsing a VMDK file to calculate its size, the format_inspector
determines the location of the Descriptor section by reading two
uint64 from the headers of the file and uses them to create the
descriptor CaptureRegion.

It would be possible to craft a VMDK file that commands the
format_inspector to create a very big CaptureRegion, thus exhausting
resources on the glance-api process.

This patch binds the beginning of the descriptor to 0x200 and limits
the size of the CaptureRegion to 1MB, similar to how the VMDK
descriptor is parsed by qemu.

VHDX:
It is a bit more involved, but similar: when looking for the
VIRTUAL_DISK_SIZE metadata, the format_inspector was creating an
unbounded CaptureRegion.

In the same way as it seems to be done in Qemu, we now limit the upper
bound of this CaptureRegion.

Closes-Bug: #2006490
Change-Id: I3ec5a33df20e1cfb6673f4ff1c7c91aacd065532
(cherry picked from commit d4d33ee30f303f783c0640cd72acb31b313e1164)
'}]
commit_message:
Limit CaptureRegion sizes in format_inspector for VMDK and VHDX

VMDK:
When parsing a VMDK file to calculate its size, the format_inspector
determines the location of the Descriptor section by reading two
uint64 from the headers of the file and uses them to create the
descriptor CaptureRegion.

It would be possible to craft a VMDK file that commands the
format_inspector to create a very big CaptureRegion, thus exhausting
resources on the glance-api process.

This patch binds the beginning of the descriptor to 0x200 and limits
the size of the CaptureRegion to 1MB, similar to how the VMDK
descriptor is parsed by qemu.

VHDX:
It is a bit more involved, but similar: when looking for the
VIRTUAL_DISK_SIZE metadata, the format_inspector was creating an
unbounded CaptureRegion.

In the same way as it seems to be done in Qemu, we now limit the upper
bound of this CaptureRegion.

Closes-Bug: #2006490
Change-Id: I3ec5a33df20e1cfb6673f4ff1c7c91aacd065532
(cherry picked from commit d4d33ee30f303f783c0640cd72acb31b313e1164)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/90/872990/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: VHDX_METADATA_TABLE_MAX_SIZE = 32 * 2048 # From qemu item_length = min(item_length, self.VHDX_METADATA_TABLE_MAX_SIZE) # The beginning and max size of the descriptor is also hardcoded in Qemu # at 0x200 and 1MB - 1 DESC_OFFSET = 0x200 DESC_MAX_SIZE = (1 << 20) - 1 # Since we parse both desc_sec and desc_num (the location of the # VMDK's descriptor, expressed in 512 bytes sectors) we enforce a # check on the bounds to create a reasonable CaptureRegion. This # is similar to how it's done in qemu. desc_offset = desc_sec * 512 desc_size = min(desc_num * 512, self.DESC_MAX_SIZE) if desc_offset != self.DESC_OFFSET: raise ImageFormatError("Wrong descriptor location") desc_offset, desc_size))

commit_message:
Add tasks to configure swap file/partion

For nova-compute, swap must be enabled by default.

Port existing t-h-t extraconfigs for swap by file or partition.

Add the swap config task into deploy-tripleo-os-install.yml.

Add CAP_SYS_ADMIN for molecule podman driver config so that it could
execute the swapon command under test.

Change-Id: I2b0e79ffc9cbc114d3f22609f5aee10a3c516b0a
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

added_lines: --- # Copyright 2022 Red Hat, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. - name: Configure swap file become: true when: - not tripleo_nova_compute_swap_partition|bool shell: | #!/bin/bash set -eu if [ ! -f {{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} ]; then dd if=/dev/zero of={{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} count={{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_size_megabytes }} bs=1M chmod 0600 {{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} mkswap {{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} swapon {{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} if ! grep -qE "{{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }}\b" /etc/fstab; then echo "{{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} swap swap defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab fi fi - name: Configure swap partiion become: true when: - tripleo_nova_compute_swap_partition|bool shell: | #!/bin/bash set -eu changed=1 if [ -e "/dev/disk/by-label/{{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_partition_label }}" ]; then swap_partition=$(realpath /dev/disk/by-label/{{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_partition_label }}) if ! grep -qE "${swap_partition}\b" /etc/fstab; then echo "$swap_partition swap swap defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab changed=0 fi else for item in $(lsblk -f --output FSTYPE,UUID | awk '/swap/ {print $2}'); do if ! grep -qe "${item}" /etc/fstab; then echo -e "UUID=${item} swap swap defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab changed=0 fi done fi if [ $changed -eq 0 ]; then swapon -a fi

commit_message:
Use /run/nova/ for nova-comp delay script

Nova have no permissions to write into /run.
Use /run/nova instead, and ensure its creation by the systemd tmpfiles

Change-Id: I010f6b8190b0897917d9fb507f626d50c5564a28
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Disable B113 rule of bandit

The new release of bandit just came out which introduced the new rule,
with which unfortunately heat is not compliant now.

This disables the rule temporally so that we can avoid adapting our
stable branches to new lint rules by backporting this.

Change-Id: I4a27049d40760ad8da6fda24e1195e26ef9c6c17

commit_message:
Disable B113 rule of bandit

The new release of bandit just came out which introduced the new rule,
with which unfortunately heat is not compliant now.

This disables the rule temporally so that we can avoid adapting our
stable branches to new lint rules by backporting this.

Change-Id: I4a27049d40760ad8da6fda24e1195e26ef9c6c17
(cherry picked from commit 4fcbe943385d01b2e9c34db2a7c5738edb4c169d)

commit_message:
Update replica state before promote.

During promote of replica, retrieve replica state from backend before
promotion. In case DB state is in-sync, but backend reports out-sync,
abort promotion.

Closes-bug: #1989126
Change-Id: I60cfaeef18cc9040d3d25c62490baddbf9767539
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/39/856539/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - During promotion of replica, replica state is retrieved from DB and it is updated by periodic task for every 5 minute. User try to promote replica looking at DB state, while actual state in backend might be different. Fix this by fetching latest replica state from backend before promotion.

commit_message:
Ceph: Disable IPv4 when IPv6 should be used

... instead of enabling both of IPv4 and IPv6. This allows us to detect
any configurations relying on IPv4.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-ceph/+/876750
Change-Id: Ic5e428013d079d7bf4f759cd9af1b52b36b2cfb2

commit_message:
Add oslo.policy.enforcer entry point

this will allow various oslo.policy scripts like
oslopolicy-policy-generator to work with Aodh.

Change-Id: I5941fe03277368f789a0e07d823ececdf86ed37e
Story: 2010559
Task: 47247

subject: Check whether live_migration_permit_post_copy=True
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-09 13:12:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/78507a35a53aaa787200379591273de7425792e9', 'message': 'Check whether live_migration_permit_post_copy=True

When live_migration_permit_post_copy is set to true, then the live
migration does not work for paused instances (see linked bug).

This patch introduces new option
[compute-feature-enabled].live_migration_permit_post_copy. When this
option is set to true then tests that perform live migration of paused
instances are skipped.

commit_message:
Check whether live_migration_permit_post_copy=True

When live_migration_permit_post_copy is set to true, then the live
migration does not work for paused instances (see linked bug).

This patch introduces new option
[compute-feature-enabled].live_migration_permit_post_copy. When this
option is set to true then tests that perform live migration of paused
instances are skipped.

Related-Bug: #1671011
Change-Id: I8b69303000be8e089912aa442d90f7951cf30489
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/66/876966/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make the network_data search more inclusive

It's possible to also use --networks-file instead of
-n in the overcloud deploy command. This change adds
a secondary search string to the awk command to ensure
we capture the file regardless of which argument has
been used in the overcloud deploy script.

Resolves: rhbz#2064354
Change-Id: I13137b558b8a55f22462a2c6a26cdb8616fdc64e

commit_message:
Support tunables for announce_self sending

We already added support from the option to enable this feature[1].
This makes some tunables of the feature so that operators can customize
some options using the native interfaces.

[1] 4a77e0a5b9b46ff33e86a7e117a021dd15b7400e

Change-Id: I68533b2166e93efcc73227619181fc95809d12d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/17/876817/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*qemu_monitor_announce_self_count*] # (Optional) The total number of times to send the announce_self command to # the QEMU monitor when enable_qemu_monitor_announce_self is enabled. # Defaults to $facts['os_service_default'] # # [*qemu_monitor_announce_self_interval*] # (Optional) The number of seconds to wait before re-sending the announce_self # command to the QEMU monitor. # Defaults to $facts['os_service_default'] # $qemu_monitor_announce_self_count = $facts['os_service_default'], $qemu_monitor_announce_self_interval = $facts['os_service_default'], 'workarounds/qemu_monitor_announce_self_count': value => $qemu_monitor_announce_self_count; 'workarounds/qemu_monitor_announce_self_interval': value => $qemu_monitor_announce_self_interval;

commit_message:
Add support for [ovs] of_listen_address/port

... so that we can use IPv6 address instead of the default IPv4 local
address.

Change-Id: I5baa7e7dfac33e267790525dc1e8b963c3166cc0

commit_message:
Add Axel as release liaison

Axel stepped up as DPTL to mistral team. Renat is mostly inactive, so
let's replace him with Axel. Adding Axel's email address that is used
in gerrit, so that our PTL-Approved flag can be triggered by his
reviews.

Change-Id: I109a254ab8b0d602b6ac53e780378a2477915b25

commit_message:
Neutron: Enable metering agent only when Telemetry is enabled

The metering-agent service is an optional service to gather metrics in
Telemetry(ceilometer + gnocchi), thus is usually disabled if Telemetry
is disabled.

This change disables the service in the scenarios without Telemetry so
that we can validate deployments without this optional service.

Change-Id: I6f1bb575b891318ac83e26450d7b0699a1911b66

commit_message:
Horizon: Completely switch to PyMemcache backend

We replaced[1] the deprecated MemcachedCache backend in CentOS[1] but
has been using the deprecated backend in Ubuntu because of the old
package in Ubuntu Focal.

Now we use Ubuntu Jammy which provides python3-pymemcache 3.5.0, so can
use PyMemcacheCache backend

[1] a0bfa42751c35358f135e791f90af97e6d92cf32

Change-Id: I609b8a7da6668185294d50b92344fbfa1d3f9db2

subject: Add further workaround features for qemu_monitor_announce_self
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-12-13 09:58:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d01e0b5b93f04e56aa017d4c17a14f270a17b839', 'message': 'Add further workaround features for qemu_monitor_announce_self

In some cases on Arista VXLAN fabrics, VMs are inaccessible via network
after live migration, despite garps being observed on the fabric itself.

This patch builds on the feature
``[workarounds]/enable_qemu_monitor_announce_self`` feature as reported
in `bug 1815989 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1815989>`

This patch adds the ability to announce_self QEMU command and add the
ability to send additional announce_self commands at a given delay
interval, as in some cases, multiple announce_self monitor commands are
required for the fabric to honor the garp packets and the VM to become
accessible via network again after live migration.

Closes-Bug: #1996995
Change-Id: I2f5bf7c9de621bb1dc7fae5b3374629a4fcc1f46
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-12-22 12:08:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7ccba24b7ad19b1bc348de1de6d25af7f78303f9', 'message': 'Add further workaround features for qemu_monitor_announce_self

In some cases on Arista VXLAN fabrics, VMs are inaccessible via network
after live migration, despite garps being observed on the fabric itself.

This patch builds on the feature
``[workarounds]/enable_qemu_monitor_announce_self`` feature as reported
in `bug 1815989 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1815989>`

This patch adds the ability to announce_self QEMU command and add the
ability to send additional announce_self commands at a given delay
interval, as in some cases, multiple announce_self monitor commands are
required for the fabric to honor the garp packets and the VM to become
accessible via network again after live migration.

Closes-Bug: #1996995
Change-Id: I2f5bf7c9de621bb1dc7fae5b3374629a4fcc1f46
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2022-12-22 16:13:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/593a57b50b0114982d80f236a9569e31cdcd6bea', 'message': 'Add further workaround features for qemu_monitor_announce_self

In some cases on Arista VXLAN fabrics, VMs are inaccessible via network
after live migration, despite garps being observed on the fabric itself.

This patch builds on the feature
``[workarounds]/enable_qemu_monitor_announce_self`` feature as reported
in `bug 1815989 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1815989>`

This patch adds the ability to announce_self QEMU command and add the
ability to send additional announce_self commands at a given delay
interval, as in some cases, multiple announce_self monitor commands are

commit_message:
Add further workaround features for qemu_monitor_announce_self

In some cases on Arista VXLAN fabrics, VMs are inaccessible via network
after live migration, despite garps being observed on the fabric itself.

This patch builds on the feature
``[workarounds]/enable_qemu_monitor_announce_self`` feature as reported
in `bug 1815989 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1815989>`

This patch adds the ability to config the number of times the QEMU
announce_self monitor command is called, and add a new configuration option to
specify a delay between calling the announce_self command multiple times,
as in some cases, multiple announce_self monitor commands are required for
the fabric to honor the garp packets and the VM to become accessible via
the network after live migration.

Closes-Bug: #1996995
Change-Id: I2f5bf7c9de621bb1dc7fae5b3374629a4fcc1f46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/24/867324/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('enable_qemu_monitor_announce_max_retries', default=3, min=0, help=""" The number of times to re-send the announce_self command to the QEMU monitor, in addition to the first attempt. If max_retries is set to 3, there will be a total of four calls to the QEMU announce_self command. Related options: * :oslo.config:option:`DEFAULT.compute_driver` (libvirt) """), cfg.IntOpt('enable_qemu_monitor_announce_retry_interval', default=1, min=0, help=""" The number of seconds to wait before re-sending the announce_self command to the QEMU monitor. Related options: * :oslo.config:option:`DEFAULT.compute_driver` (libvirt) """),
