commit_message:
Pin nettle-3.8-3 on ubi9 only

This patch fixes the workaround proposed in [1] to install
nettle-3.8-3 only on ubi9 containers.
Since we are backporting this fix to stable/wallaby, we need
to guarantee that doesn't break ubi8 containers.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/869104

Change-Id: I039ca97773699f6f744e83172dd6664ace0d8d60
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/96/876896/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO: Temporary pinning nettle to 3.8-3.el9, so it can be reinstalled from centos-9 repos. # nettle-3.8-3 is already installed in ubi9 image, but it conflicts with newer versions on gnutls # installed from centos-9 repos. This workaround can be reverted once ubi9.2 is released, which # should contain a newer version of gnutls with fixes to run under FIPS mode. # See: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2154924 and # https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1984237 - run: >- if [ '{{ tcib_release }}' == '9' ];then dnf -y install nettle-3.8-3.el9; fi
deleted_lines: # TODO: Temporary pinning nettle to 3.8-3.el9, so it can be reinstalled from centos-9 repos. # nettle-3.8-3 is already installed in ubi9 image, but it conflicts with newer versions on gnutls # installed from centos-9 repos. This workaround can be reverted once ubi9.2 is released, which # should contain a newer version of gnutls with fixes to run under FIPS mode. - nettle-3.8-3.el9

subject: Shrinking: add states and biggest_candidate root recon metrics
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-12-02 05:11:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/b232f5ffd219f353907bff5934a019cab4cbd336', 'message': "Add some shard health metrics

This patch adds some new shard related metrics that will extend our
current shard health metrics:

  1. shard_list.visited_shards.<num>:
    This metric is fired down in the container controller in the
    proxy and basically counts the number of shards it had to talk
    to to build a listing response [1]
    Note however, shards it visits may then recurse into sub-shards,
    these aren't tracked. Just the number of shards it walked through
    at the upper level.

    The metric is fires off is based on now many it had to visit. In a
    healthy distributed root container, each shard should be quite
    large, with a 10,000 list limit, this number should almost always be
    a 1 or 2 to build a listing response. If it has to visit many more
    shards to build up the 10,000 max limit then this is an indication
    of alot of small shards that may need to be shrunk.

  2. audit_root.range_count.<n-1>000_<n>000:
    This metric is fired from audit_root_container in the sharder. It
    will track the number of shard ranges are in a root, and fire of a
    metric based on which thousand'th the container is in.
    Anything < 1000 will be in:

       audit_root.range_count.0000_1000

    Something that has more then 7000 shard ranges but less the 8k:

      audit_root.range_count.7000_8000

    I suspect most container will be in the 0000_1000, so this count
    should be high. But we'd start seeing how many large containers in
    the cluster.
    Note however, this will be fired from a sharder as it visits a root
    container, so if your aggregating, you might want to divide by the
    container replica count.

With these two metrics, we should get a better pickure of the overall
distribution and size health of shards in a cluster.

Another reason for this patch, is so when we do get shrinking happening,
we should see improvements via these metrics.

Change-Id: Ie39e83fe1d20518fdc68c24436c6b1e278e5690a
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-12-04 23:42:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/b05be719ccba40f034dd241b5e0536677616f560', 'message': "Add some shard health metrics

This patch adds some new shard related metrics that will extend our
current shard health metrics:

  1. shard_list.visited_shards.<num>:
    This metric is fired down in the container controller in the
    proxy and basically counts the number of shards it had to talk
    to to build a listing response [1]
    Note however, shards it visits may then recurse into sub-shards,
    these aren't tracked. Just the number of shards it walked through
    at the upper level.

    The metric is fires off is based on now many it had to visit. In a
    healthy distributed root container, each shard should be quite
    large, with a 10,000 list limit, this number should almost always be
    a 1 or 2 to build a listing response. If it has to visit many more
    shards to build up the 10,000 max limit then this is an indication
    of alot of small shards that may need to be shrunk.

  2. audit_root.range_count.<n-1>000_<n>000:
    This metric is fired from audit_root_container in the sharder. It
    will track the number of shard ranges are in a root, and fire of a
    metric based on which thousand'th the container is in.
    Anything < 1000 will be in:

       audit_root.range_count.0000_1000

    Something that has more then 7000 shard ranges but less the 8k:

      audit_root.range_count.7000_8000

    I suspect most container will be in the 0000_1000, so this count
    should be high. But we'd start seeing how many large containers in
    the cluster.
    Note however, this will be fired from a sharder as it visits a root
    container, so if your aggregating, you might want to divide by the
    container replica count.

With these two metrics, we should get a better pickure of the overall
distribution and size health of shards in a cluster.

Another reason for this patch, is so when we do get shrinking happening,
we should see improvements via these metrics.

Change-Id: Ie39e83fe1d20518fdc68c24436c6b1e278e5690a
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2023-01-30 06:43:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/0868d3970070f015cf1b49c3bf151fdbbdf24a4e', 'message': "Shrinking: add states and biggest root recon metrics

When looking at shrinking candidates it might be nice to know how many
active ranges there are to compare against the number of compactable
ranges. Further when tracking the progress of cleaving (cleaving or
shrinking) knowing how many ranges are in the shrinking state would also
be nice to track.

This patch adds shrinking to the state_count used by the
sharding_inprogress code, but also includes the state_count in the
shrinking candidates, shrinking candidates are root containers and
knowing how many ranges are in what state is interesting.

To have a rough idea of how big our biggest root containers are getting,
now collect this and report the biggest (most active shards) for a
sharding cycle and record it as 'biggest' in the sharding recon dump.

Change-Id: Ie39e83fe1d20518fdc68c24436c6b1e278e5690a
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2023-02-17 03:30:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/aa13026e38d1526c1ea576b6f058ed43f54d427a', 'message': "Shrinking: add states and biggest_candidate root recon metrics

active ranges there are to compare against the number of compactable

This patch adds shrinking to the state_count used by the

commit_message:
Shrinking: add states and biggest_candidate root recon metrics

When looking at shrinking candidates it might be nice to know how many
active ranges there are to compare against the number of compactable
ranges. Further when tracking the progress of cleaving (cleaving or
shrinking) knowing how many ranges are in the shrinking state would also
be nice to track.

This patch adds shrinking to the state_count used by the
sharding_inprogress code, but also includes the state_count in the
shrinking candidates, shrinking candidates are root containers and
knowing how many ranges are in what state is interesting.

Something else we're missing is the ability to track the largest roots
in the cluster. When auditing a root container, this patch also tracks
the top x biggest (active shard count) root containers and reports them
in the recon dump as the biggest_candidates.

Change-Id: Ie39e83fe1d20518fdc68c24436c6b1e278e5690a

commit_message:
Check VMDK subformat against an allowed list

Also add a more general check to convert_image that the image format
reported by qemu-img matches what the caller says it is.

Change-Id: I3c60ee4c0795aadf03108ed9b5a46ecd116894af
Partial-bug: #1996188
(cherry picked from commit 930fc93e9fda82a4aa4568ae149c3c80af7379d0)
(cherry picked from commit ba37dc2ead69c08d7ede242295ff997086e6121d)
Conflicts:
  cinder/image/image_utils.py
   - changed type annotations to use implicit Optional to be
     consistent with cinder yoga mypy usage
   - removed refs to image_conversion_disable in tests
(cherry picked from commit 2ae5d53526e2b224d81b3259140c59aba97d72c3)
(cherry picked from commit e96415409daa158cc503c1adec1ca1ca4f940082)
Conflicts:
  cinder/image/image_utils.py
   - removed type annotations
   - restored wallaby-era fetch_verify_image() function signature
(cherry picked from commit be11d54ac420e0ebc0da6917d7ffc3af59b40f24)
Conflicts:
  cinder/tests/unit/test_image_utils.py
   - did not include extraneous test from be11d54ac's parent commit
Additions:
  cinder/image/image_utils.py
   - added code to handle oslo.utils<4.1.0,>=3.14.0
  cinder/tests/unit/test_image_utils.py
   - added a test for ^^
(cherry picked from commit 17565262dafb5beeaec8e9e249e760fc64f3df93)
Conflicts:
  cinder/image/image_utils.py
   - removed src_passphrase_file parameter to convert_image() that was
     introduced in victoria by change I896f70d204ad103e
  cinder/tests/unit/test_image_utils.py
   - removed references to ddt.TestNameFormat (not present in this
     version of ddt)
(cherry picked from commit 9902c17927b69e0b2379dfe8d2a2b89244162526)
Additions:
  cinder/tests/unit/test_image_utils.py
   - added code to handle oslo.utils<4.1.0 when running unit tests under
     Python 2.7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/31/871631/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | This release introduces a new configuration option, ``vmdk_allowed_types``, that specifies the list of VMDK image subformats that Cinder will allow. The default setting allows only the 'streamOptimized' and 'monolithicSparse' subformats, which do not use named extents. security: - | This release introduces a new configuration option, ``vmdk_allowed_types``, that specifies the list of VMDK image subformats that Cinder will allow in order to prevent exposure of host information by modifying the named extents in a VMDK image. The default setting allows only the 'streamOptimized' and 'monolithicSparse' subformats, which do not use named extents. - | As part of the fix for `Bug #1996188 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1996188>`_, cinder is now more strict in checking that the ``disk_format`` recorded for an image (as revealed by the Image Service API image-show response) matches what cinder detects when it downloads the image. Thus, some requests to create a volume from a source image that had previously succeeded may fail with an ``ImageUnacceptable`` error. fixes: - | `Bug #1996188 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1996188>`_: Fixed issue where a VMDK image file whose createType allowed named extents could expose host information. This change introduces a new configuration option, ``vmdk_allowed_types``, that specifies the list of VMDK image subformats that Cinder will allow. The default setting allows only the 'streamOptimized' and 'monolithicSparse' subformats.

commit_message:
Add the main NebulOuS repos

The NebulOuS project aims to deliver a Meta Operating System and
Fog Brokerage Platform for transient cloud continuum ecosystems. [1]

This patch follows the Project Creator's Guide to create a new
project in OpenDev's collaboratory.

It also creates the project-config repo in preparation for the creation
of a new Zuul tenant: nebulous.

[1] https://www.nebulouscloud.eu/

Change-Id: I369177cd43f92f02a73011b46545210015d5112a

commit_message:
Backport openstack_testing from Yoga

At the moment we're facing issues with tempest failing to install
all required plugins due to not matching constraints with requirements

In order to prevent that we used to fix plugin versions directly in the
tempest role in an ad-hoc manner. However, it's better to use
correct and working versions of plugins for the branch, so SHAs were
backported from Y which should work correctly.

Also according to no objections raised during the meeting [1], we're
disabling upgrade jobs from branches that are currently in EM, since
we don't need to block current development due to EM failures.

[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ansible/%23openstack-ansible.2023-03-07.log.html#t2023-03-07T15:06:59

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server/+/875782
Change-Id: I11f5326724ac1af00166f2d6d86cd3427470fea0

subject: Add charms-stable-maint group for charms projects
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-02-01 12:19:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/de5383a18f4c4a40df6f26860a498f5eba308a1a', 'message': "Add charms-stable-maint group for charms projects

We've decided to add a new group to help manage stable maintenance of
the stable branches in the charms group of projects.  Note that
charms-ceph and charms-vault are part of the charms set of projects but

commit_message:
Add charms-stable-maint group for charms projects

We've decided to add a new group to help manage stable maintenance of
the stable branches in the charms group of projects.  Note that
charms-ceph and charms-vault are part of the charms set of projects but
already have slightly different groups of maintainers.

Change-Id: Ibcb89c87a15d72d05b6a9f599aede3a7b60f4df6

commit_message:
Periodically update Puppetfile_unit

This updates the script to automatically update puppet constraints so
that Puppetfile_unit is updated as well as Puppetfile. We introduced
this separate file[1] a while ago but have not been updated it
properly. Updating it periodically helps us catch up with any update
in the dependent modules more timely.

[1] 047ea125ddefa8151d6592d4772560a1b23a13dc

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/875301
Change-Id: I4d89a2985781f14d9ff7f76f412f0b8ccc4c6ddb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/02/875302/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # header echo -e "# Auto-generated Puppetfile for Puppet OpenStack project\n" > $DIR/Puppetfile_unit # OpenStack Modules echo "## OpenStack modules" >> $DIR/Puppetfile for p in $(cat openstack_modules.txt); do # hack for puppet-openstack-integration # where namespace is openstack_integration title=$(echo $p | sed 's/-/_/g') # TODO(emilien) we need to add support for stable branches cat >> $DIR/Puppetfile <<EOF mod '$title', :git => 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-$p', :ref => 'master' EOF done # Unit test Modules echo -e "## External modules" >> $DIR/Puppetfile_unit for e in $(cat unit_modules.txt); do namespace=$(echo $e | awk -F'/' '{print $1}' | cut -d "," -f 1) module=$(echo $e | awk -F'/' '{print $2}' | cut -d "," -f 1) title=$(echo $module | awk -F'/' '{print $1}' | cut -d "-" -f 2) pin=$(echo $e | grep "," | cut -d "," -f 2) if [ ! -z "$pin" ]; then git ls-remote --exit-code https://github.com/$namespace/$module $pin if (($? == 2)); then if ! git ls-remote --exit-code https://github.com/$namespace/$module | grep -q $pin; then echo "Wrong pin: $pin does not exist in $module module." exit 1 else tag=$pin fi else tag=$pin fi else git clone https://github.com/$namespace/$module modules/$module tag=$(cd modules/$module; git describe --tags $(git rev-list --tags --max-count=1)) rm -rf modules/$module fi cat >> $DIR/Puppetfile_unit <<EOF mod '$title', :git => 'https://github.com/$namespace/$module', :ref => '$tag' EOF done # for debug cat $DIR/Puppetfile_unit

commit_message:
Retire puppet-tacker - Step 1: End project Gating

This module has not attracted any interest and has been unmaintained.
We asked any feedback[1] about retiring this module but have received
no objections so far, so we can assume no one is really using it.

[1] https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2023-January/031894.html

Change-Id: I223a1e304eefc13d90b637087db3554bb6244142

commit_message:
gerrit/acl : submit-requirements for deprecated NoOp function

The submit functions are deprecated in Gerrit 3.7 and replaced with
submit-requirements.

This starts at the replacement with ACL's currently using the NoOp
function.

This implements the migrations steps encded with [1] upstream.  The
function is changed to NoBlock, and a "non-applicable"
submit-requirement of "applicableIf = is:false" and "submittableIf =
is:true" is added, with the same name as the label.

Since we are matching the upstream rules for idempotence -- a
submit-requirement with the same name as the label, we will avoid
future upgrades modifying our ACL's and getting them out of sync with
what we have in project-config.

From a user's point-of-view, this change itself should be a no-op.

[1] https://gerrit-review.googlesource.com/c/gerrit/+/339542

Change-Id: Ic43f561174ebf30474b1b54be2bed02695cebedc

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I767e24e68eaf430cb9ba6439bf999fda2882153e

subject: Do not use 'always' tag in inappropriate places
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-01 17:34:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server/commit/730e84e3ef01cfca0e5a0f40a9e7017e719c41bb', 'message': "Do not use 'always' tag in inappropriate places

Using 'always' tag in combination with condition depending on
variables is not always a good idea because these variables may not be
defined at the moment.

Currently, rabbitmq_server role cannot be executed with tag limit,
because task containing 'always' tag has a condition operating on
variable(s) that are registered only when 'rabbitmq-config' tag is being
used.

Using 'always' tag in combination with condition depending on

commit_message:
Do not use 'always' tag in inappropriate places

Using 'always' tag in combination with condition depending on
variables is not always a good idea because these variables may not be
defined at the moment.

Currently, rabbitmq_server role cannot be executed with tag limit,
because task containing 'always' tag has a condition operating on
variable(s) that are registered only when 'rabbitmq-config' tag is being
used.

Change-Id: I7ef7b3fed79933b4c8bbc39a63ca6db54532e10e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server refs/changes/71/875971/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fixes repositories files name in Rocky Linux 9

Distributions moved to lowercase names with RHEL 9 release.
This patch also removes previously created uppercase files.

Story: 2010637
Task: 47604
Change-Id: I8bf75ce44b9ec1fdd477fcddf2deebf2929d9fc1
(cherry picked from commit e0ff9a0283bd870df72ea7dec62d55ef0b8ed972)

commit_message:
WIP: Pin pylint tox env to python 3.9

Pylint on python 3.10 returns numerous spurious
no-member errors about the 'os' module.

This gets it to provide useful output instead.

Discussion here points to related issues:
https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/6535#issuecomment-1344826489

Change-Id: I85782e7312a263881b1bdcf820d717422fe6471a

commit_message:
Sync default policy rules

This patch updates default policy-in-code rules in horizon based on
nova/neutron/cinder RC deliverables. It doesn't update policy
rules for glance and keystone as I have found no changes in their
policy rules. Horizon needs to update default policy-in-code rules
for all backend services before releasing the horizon[1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/contributor/policies/releasing.html#things-to-do-before-releasing

Change-Id: Iae50f131be3f7d1345b8b899b70da8301700428c

commit_message:
Removing helper functions providing Python < 3.3 compatibility

Functions used for deriving terminal width are no longer
necessary, as Python 3.3 introduced[0] built in solution.

Remaining helper function `utils.terminal_width` received docstring
explaining return parameters.

Method `_assign_max_widths` of the `TableFormatter` class was refactored
to no longer use the `stdout` argument. Uses of the method were adjusted accordingly.
Method now also has minimal docstring. Minor adjustment was made to inline comments
to more closely reflect functionality of the code.

[0]https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/os.html?highlight=get_terminal_size#os.get_terminal_size

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I2898f099227e8c97aef6492c60f2f99038aa1357
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cliff refs/changes/89/862689/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def terminal_width(): """Return terminal width in columns Uses `os.get_terminal_size` function :returns: terminal width :rtype: int or None """ try: return os.get_terminal_size().columns except OSError:
deleted_lines: import ctypesimport struct import sysdef terminal_width(stdout): if hasattr(os, 'get_terminal_size'): # python 3.3 onwards has built-in support for getting terminal size try: return os.get_terminal_size().columns except OSError: return None if sys.platform == 'win32': return _get_terminal_width_windows(stdout) else: return _get_terminal_width_ioctl(stdout) def _get_terminal_width_windows(stdout): STD_INPUT_HANDLE = -10 STD_OUTPUT_HANDLE = -11 STD_ERROR_HANDLE = -12 std_to_win_handle = { sys.stdin: STD_INPUT_HANDLE, sys.stdout: STD_OUTPUT_HANDLE, sys.stderr: STD_ERROR_HANDLE} std_handle = std_to_win_handle.get(stdout) if not std_handle: return None handle = ctypes.windll.kernel32.GetStdHandle(std_handle) csbi = ctypes.create_string_buffer(22) res = ctypes.windll.kernel32.GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo(handle, csbi) if res: (size_x, size_y, cur_pos_x, cur_pos_y, attr, left, top, right, bottom, max_size_x, max_size_y) = struct.unpack( "hhhhHhhhhhh", csbi.raw) return size_x def _get_terminal_width_ioctl(stdout): from fcntl import ioctl import termios try: # winsize structure has 4 unsigned short fields winsize = b'\0' * struct.calcsize('hhhh') try: winsize = ioctl(stdout, termios.TIOCGWINSZ, winsize) except IOError: return None except TypeError: # this is raised in unit tests as stdout is sometimes a StringIO return None winsize = struct.unpack('hhhh', winsize) columns = winsize[1] if not columns: return None return columns except IOError:

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Iac3bf10942721195369d095149e1015fe0c9f8ef

subject: docker: Set ulimit nofile on EL9
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-02 11:35:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-collection-kolla/commit/7539c94411164af2f392b78953420e38a366a8a6', 'message': "docker: Set ulimit nofile on EL9

Some latest RPM-based distributions, such as RHEL 9 and CentOS Stream 9, ship
a recent version of systemd that sets the default open file handle limit is
set to 1073741816.
That effects in various issues (like rabbitmq not working), including
ceph/other services in containers not working properly.
kolla-ansible has set that as a default ulimit for Kolla container images [1],
this patch sets that as a Docker Engine default (for container images
that don't have this overridden).

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/839715

commit_message:
docker: Set ulimit nofile on EL9

Some latest RPM-based distributions, such as RHEL 9 and CentOS Stream 9, ship
a recent version of systemd that sets the default open file handle limit is
set to 1073741816.
That effects in various issues (like rabbitmq not working), including
ceph/other services in containers not working properly.
kolla-ansible has set that as a default ulimit for Kolla container images [1],
this patch sets that as a Docker Engine default (for container images
that don't have this overridden).

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/839715

Closes-Bug: #2008761

Change-Id: I48a8f18287aa3b017ce04d4b076d88989f927a56
(cherry picked from commit d985ef48b29f3cdbae9ff9f45f598d6a224545fd)
(cherry picked from commit b7afb0339e21372a18512f6934362857efbb54b0)

commit_message:
Deprecate DHCP providers

The DHCP providers are deprecated and will be removed in Rocky release.

For those who using custom dhcp providers, custom network_interfaces
or custom deploy drivers. The network_interfaces should implement
`clean_dhcp` and `get_ip_addresses` methods. DHCP options are now set
when calling the following methods from network_interface and may be
passed as optional parameter `dhcp_opts`:

    * `add_provisioning_network`
    * `add_cleaning_network`
    * `configure_tenant_networks`

Closes-Bug: #1683777

Change-Id: I28960f499c0655f1e6c90044161bd88931912f79

subject: Clean invalid conflict response usages
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-22 15:24:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/commit/e7f2677ad87e1ba71af24c308e006e4e10a43cd6', 'message': 'Clean invalid conflict response usages and unneccessary retries

This spec describes how to replace invalid usages of conflict response,
and how to descrease the load on Ironic API by that

commit_message:
Clean invalid conflict response usages

This spec describes how to replace invalid usages of conflict response
in ironic-api.

Change-Id: I373d74b95ce638f4f740b836c01cac36704dd09b
Partial-Bug: #1651447

commit_message:
Add hardware properties API to management interface

This spec proposes to extend driver management interface, add support
for "standardized" properties.

Related-bug: #1526475

Change-Id: I56030124beb7e2e8f94c2162e37cbb25fcb49220
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/12/209612/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== New driver interface for BIOS configuration =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/ironic-firmware-interface This spec presents a new driver interface for support BIOS and firmware settings configuration. Problem description =================== * There is no generic way in Ironic to do BIOS/FW configuration. * User should be able to get list of supported parameters and values from the driver. * Ironic should update capabilities of a node when corresponding parameters were changed. Proposed change =============== * New driver interface ``FirmwareInterface`` will be provided for BIOS/FW configuration. * New REST API endpoints will be created for setting and retrieving the BIOS/FW properties. * User gets/sets BIOS/FW configuration information for Ironic driver via REST API as JSON data. Example 1 of expose available parameters:: { 'bios': { [ { 'name': 'parameter1', 'description': 'setting foo', 'values': [0, 1, 2, 3], 'default': 0, 'capabilities': {'foo': {0: 'off', 3: 'on'}} 'reset_needed': True }, { 'name': 'parameter2', 'description': 'setting bar', 'values': ['stop', 'start'], 'apply_online': True }, ] }, 'controller1': { [ { 'name': 'parameter3', 'description': 'setting controller1', 'values': [8, 10], }, ] } In example above: * 'bios', 'controller1': names of configurable devices, mandatory. * 'name': name of parameter, mandatory. * 'description': human readable description, optional. * 'values': list of supported values, mandatory. * 'default': default value, optional. * 'capabilities': name and values of linked capabilities, optional. * 'apply_online': can be applied on the fly in any state of a node, optional, default is False. * 'reset_needed': node reset required after change, optional, default is True. Example 2 of expose current values:: { 'bios': { 'version': '1.09.2015E' 'settings': { parameter1': 2, parameter2': 'stop', }, }, 'controller1': { 'version': '1-0-567.k' 'settings': { 'parameter3': 10, }, } In example above: * 'version': firmware version string, mandatory, empty if unknown. Example 3 of setting new values:: { 'bios': { 'parameter2': 'start', }, 'controller1': { 'parameter3': 8, }, } Update BIOS/FW settings workflow: #. Driver does validate of user's parameters. #. If parameter(s) can be applied on the fly driver does update immediately. #. If parameter(s) can not be applied immediately driver saves them in node.driver_internal_info field with 'firmware_settings' key ('firmware_settings': {'bios': {'foo': 'bar'}}). #. Postponed parameters applied during zapping or cleaning procedure. #. Driver updates node capabilities if there are linked capabilities. Alternatives ------------ * Developers can use vendor passthru mechanism for BIOS/FW settings. * Users can change this settings manually. Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None. REST API impact --------------- New REST API endpoints will be added: - To get BIOS/FW available parameters:: GET /v1/drivers/<driver>/firmware/properties Properties returned as example 1. - To set new parameters:: PUT /v1/nodes/NNNN/states/firmware with a BODY containing the JSON as example 3. - To get current parameters:: GET /v1/nodes/NNNN/states/firmware Parameters returned as example 2. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- New options should be added for getting/setting BIOS/FW parameters. RPC API impact -------------- New RPC API methods will be created: * ``get_firmware_properties`` - get parameters from a driver. * ``get_firmware_settings`` - get parameters for a node. * ``set_firmware_settings`` - set parameters for a node. Driver API impact ----------------- A new ``FirmwareInterface`` will be created. It will contain the following methods:: def validate(task): """Validates driver's parameters for BIOS/FW settings. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :raises: InvalidParameterValue, if configuration is invalid. :raises: MissingParameterValue, if configuration has some missing parameters. """ def get_firmware_properties(task): """Gets BIOS/FW properties defined by the driver. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :returns: A dictionary of properties. """ def get_firmware_settings(task): """Gets BIOS/FW settings for a node. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :returns: A dictionary of settings. """ def set_firmware_settings(task, settings): """Sets BIOS/FW settings for a node. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :param settings: A dictionary of settings. """ def reset_to_defaults(task, device): """Reset BIOS/FW settings for a node to factory defaults. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :param device: A name of device to reset. """ .. note:: - get_firmware_settings() method is optional, should raise NotImplementedError if not implemented. - reset_to_defaults() method can be used internally for cleaning/zapping, 'device' parameter is the name of device to reset like 'bios', 'controller1' in examples. Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Developers may implement this interface for drivers. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: yuriyz Other contributors: vdrok Work Items ---------- * Create ``FirmwareInterface`` in base and for fake driver. * Create RPC API methods. * Create REST API endpoints. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will be provided. References ========== http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/kilo-archive/drac-bios-mgmt.html

commit_message:
Documentation update for booting from volume

Boot from volume doc for Devstack is missing some of the configuration
details provided in the /admin/boot-from-volume.rst.

This patch updates /contributor/ironic-boot-from-volume.rst with creating
volume connector etc and links to /admin/boot-from-volume.rst.

Change-Id: I583a24efd233a9b5112fd990217a3499bdefe02e

added_lines: # verify the name of the cirros image for version changes DEFAULT_IMAGE_NAME=cirros-0.3.5-x86_64-disk # specify the storage interface openstack baremetal node set --storage-interface cinder --node $NODE_UUID # specify the iSCSI configuration openstack baremetal node set --property 'capabilities=iscsi_boot:True' --node $NODE_UUID # create volume connector openstack --os-baremetal-api-version 1.33 baremetal volume connector create \ --node $NODE_UUID --type iqn --connector-id iqn.2017-08.org.openstack.$NODE_UUID See :ref:`boot-from-volume` for details on booting from a cinder iSCSI volume.

commit_message:
Add missing error to log in do_node_deploy()

Helper function handle_failure() will make a log string
containing node uuid and error. But the handling process
of uploading configdrive to Swift missed the error when
calling this function. So this patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I4f020606c2dbb09140e8a639620f45fc9d8565ac

This change moves most of the common code for prepare, deploy,
tear_down and clean_up methods of agent and iscsi deploy
interfaces into the deploy_utils module.

Apart from that, iscsi deploy interface was triggering
boot.prepare_instance for nodes in ADOPTING state in the prepare method,
which in turn sets boot device. It should not be the case, as BMC of
ADOPTING nodes should not be accessed. Other things, like pxe config
switching, are necessary tho. On the other hand, agent deploy interface
was not calling boot.prepare_instance in prepare method for ADOPTING
nodes, so pxe configs did not get generated, but they should be, in case
of iscsi or netboot. This patch also fixes these inconsistencies.

Closes-Bug: #1735517

Change-Id: Iadd035cb59ccc1729f3ab3b7d61d667fedf8b6d6
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor deploy interface methods

This change moves most of the common code for prepare, deploy,
tear_down and clean_up methods of agent and iscsi deploy
interfaces into the deploy_utils module.

Apart from that, iscsi deploy interface was triggering
boot.prepare_instance for nodes in ADOPTING state in the prepare method,
which in turn sets boot device. It should not be the case, as BMC of
ADOPTING nodes should not be accessed. Other things, like pxe config
switching, are necessary tho. On the other hand, agent deploy interface
was not calling boot.prepare_instance in prepare method for ADOPTING
nodes, so pxe configs did not get generated, but they should be, in case
of iscsi or netboot. This patch also fixes these inconsistencies.

Closes-Bug: #1735517

Change-Id: Iadd035cb59ccc1729f3ab3b7d61d667fedf8b6d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/33/524433/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: # during takeover if boot_device and task.node.provision_state != states.ACTIVE:

commit_message:
list_instances - cache allocations

When listing instances fetch all allocations to a cache,
fetch each nodes allocation from the cache. This is
significantly faster than calling get_allocation for each
node.

time metealsmith list # 250 nodes:
  real 0m54.970s vs real 1m45.048s without "cached".

Story: 2010571
Task: 47318
Change-Id: Ic4cef61e338fb57bea5de4f96eb3584386cc5152
(cherry picked from commit 364fa239165702d5cedc134666046aa9de1a595b)
(cherry picked from commit 392593dd7707f7d7b90c2a96c14f7eb984d1d0d4)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith refs/changes/72/876672/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: allocations_cache = dict() Provisioner.allocations_cache = { a.id: a for a in self.connection.baremetal.allocations()} if hasattr(ident, 'allocation_id'): node = ident try: try: allocation = Provisioner.allocations_cache[ node.instance_id] except KeyError: allocation = self.connection.baremetal.get_allocation( node.allocation_id) else: node, allocation = self._find_node_and_allocation(ident) if allocation is None and node.allocation_id: try: allocation = self.connection.baremetal.get_allocation( node.allocation_id) except os_exc.ResourceNotFound as exc: raise exceptions.InstanceNotFound(str(exc))
deleted_lines: node, allocation = self._find_node_and_allocation(ident) if allocation is None and node.allocation_id: try: allocation = self.connection.baremetal.get_allocation( node.allocation_id)

commit_message:
list_instances - cache allocations

When listing instances fetch all allocations to a cache,
fetch each nodes allocation from the cache. This is
significantly faster than calling get_allocation for each
node.

time metealsmith list # 250 nodes:
  real 0m54.970s vs real 1m45.048s without "cached".

Story: 2010571
Task: 47318
Change-Id: Ic4cef61e338fb57bea5de4f96eb3584386cc5152
(cherry picked from commit 364fa239165702d5cedc134666046aa9de1a595b)
(cherry picked from commit 392593dd7707f7d7b90c2a96c14f7eb984d1d0d4)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith refs/changes/71/876671/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: allocations_cache = dict() Provisioner.allocations_cache = { a.id: a for a in self.connection.baremetal.allocations()} if hasattr(ident, 'allocation_id'): node = ident try: try: allocation = Provisioner.allocations_cache[ node.instance_id] except KeyError: allocation = self.connection.baremetal.get_allocation( node.allocation_id) else: node, allocation = self._find_node_and_allocation(ident) if allocation is None and node.allocation_id: try: allocation = self.connection.baremetal.get_allocation( node.allocation_id) except os_exc.ResourceNotFound as exc: raise exceptions.InstanceNotFound(str(exc))
deleted_lines: node, allocation = self._find_node_and_allocation(ident) if allocation is None and node.allocation_id: try: allocation = self.connection.baremetal.get_allocation( node.allocation_id)

commit_message:
Allow not writing pxe configs to disk

as part of dynamic iPXE feature implementation, we need a possibility to
not save iPXE configs to disk, as they will be returned from ironic API
instead.

This patch adds a toggle to the methods that render (i)PXE config templates
to optionally not write the template on disk.

Also these methods are now returning the actual config rendered from template
as string.

Change-Id: I65a0d7346f4c35ef8044f4c023a83768c86b2b50
Partial-Bug: #1526275
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/97/394397/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def create_service_ipxe_config(node, pxe_options, root_uuid_or_disk_id, on_disk=True): :param on_disk: if True, rendered template is written to the file on disk. :returns: tuple of template and options template was/is to be rendered with if on_disk: # TODO(pas-ha) this is legacy path for iPXE boot configs which # are not proper Jinja templates. # It should be removed once we stop supporting such # out-of-tree templates. template = fix_legacy_template(template_path) pxe_config = utils.render_template(template, template_options, is_file=False) pxe_config_file_path = pxe_utils.get_pxe_config_file_path(node.uuid) # NOTE(pas-ha) here we rely on the assumption that the proper # directories are already created, and proper MAC-based links are made # during provisioning, so that we just need to re-write existing file utils.write_to_file(pxe_config_file_path, pxe_config) return template_path, template_options
deleted_lines: def create_service_ipxe_config(node, pxe_options, root_uuid_or_disk_id): # TODO(pas-ha) this is legacy path for iPXE boot configs which # are not proper Jinja templates. # It should be removed once we stop supporting such # out-of-tree templates. template = fix_legacy_template(template_path) pxe_config = utils.render_template(template, template_options, is_file=False) pxe_config_file_path = pxe_utils.get_pxe_config_file_path(node.uuid) # NOTE(pas-ha) here we rely on the assumption that the proper # directories are already created, and proper MAC-based links are made # during provisioning, so that we just need to re-write existing file utils.write_to_file(pxe_config_file_path, pxe_config)

This patch adds ``supported_power_states`` field in the responses
of the requests to the following Ironic APIs. This feature is
supported in Ironic API microversion 1.32 and above.

commit_message:
Expose supported power states

This patch adds new api endpoints to show the current power state and
the supported power states of a node as follows:
- GET /v1/nodes/<node>/states/power
- GET /v1/nodes/<node>/states/power/supported
These endpoints are available from API version 1.37. To implement
these endpoints, NodePowerController is introduced as a sub element
of NodeStatesController.

A new RPC API, get_supported_power_states() is also added and RPC
version is bumped to 1.43.

Partial-Bug: 1734827
Change-Id: Ic4ce99d58febdb5c702ebbfc9276979e6ca6fba0
Co-Authored-By: Hironori Shiina <shiina.hironori@jp.fujitsu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/94/382194/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_supported_power_states(self, context, node_id, topic=None): """Get a list of the supported power states. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :returns: A list with the supported power states defined in :mod:`ironic.common.states`. """ cctxt = self.client.prepare(topic=topic or self.topic, version='1.35') return cctxt.call(context, 'get_supported_power_states', node_id=node_id)

commit_message:
WIP: Require keyword arguments to call common_filters

Require keyword arguments when calling the
ironicclient.utils.common.common_filters() function.

Change-Id: Ia51da3e645bc1c0ee55af3dd77d2d627dec38cfc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/16/481316/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: filters = utils.common_filters(marker=marker, limit=limit, sort_key=sort_key, sort_dir=sort_dir, fields=fields)
deleted_lines: filters = utils.common_filters(marker, limit, sort_key, sort_dir, fields)

commit_message:
Simplify logic for API version '1' and improve unit tests

Simplify the logic so that that when user sets API version to '1' it
becomes that latest version.

Change OS_BAREMETAL_API_LATEST to OS_BAREMETAL_ALLOW_API_DOWNGRADE as
the name better reflects what it is used for. Update associated
comments.

Also improve the units tests for testing the option parser to actually
have it run 'parse_args' and check that the result is what we expect.

Improve function documentation and give function a more accurate name
(_determine_default_version)

Add unit tests for the _determine_default_version() function.

Refactor checking for the 'latest' version to remove code duplication.

Add a unit test which proves comments that if the
"--os-baremetal-api-version" command line argument is not given then
ReplaceLatestVersion is not called.

Add unit tests for function added in refactoring.

Change-Id: I59c7c764663cb2c1bd96ece3bdc9e09ae6b3b409

When appropriate use a lambda for the mock.patch / mock.patch.object
'new'[1].

Rough guidelines for when appropriate:
  * Only the 'return_value' is set for the mock

  * The 'return_value' is a static value

commit_message:
WIP/DNM: Some mock cleanup for the future

Not 100% sure about this. Maybe I will get back to this.

Use lambda when appropriate for mock.patch 'new'

When appropriate use a lambda for the mock.patch / mock.patch.object
'new'[1].

Rough guidelines for when appropriate:
  * Only the 'return_value' is set for the mock
  * No assertions are checked on the mock
  * The 'return_value' is a static value
  * The 'return_value' is not too large. Roughly more than 1-2 lines.

This is not an exhaustive patch and there could be candidates for
changing that were missed.

The reason for doing this is that it cleans up the test function
argument list. Less arguments to keep track of. And is cleaner code,
in my opinion.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/unittest.mock.html#the-patchers

Change-Id: Idf67c27212559935425da0a32a6e22054b6e88ff

added_lines: # Validate pre-conditions self._provision_validate(target=target, configdrive=configdrive, clean_steps=clean_steps) if target in (ir_states.ACTIVE, ir_states.REBUILD): rebuild = (target == ir_states.REBUILD) rpc_node.uuid, rebuild=rebuild, configdrive=configdrive, topic=topic) def _provision_validate(self, target, configdrive=None, clean_steps=None): """Validate that the provision requested can proceed""" if configdrive is not None and target != ir_states.ACTIVE: msg = (_('Adding a config drive is only supported when setting ' 'provision state to %s') % ir_states.ACTIVE) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError( msg, status_code=http_client.BAD_REQUEST) if clean_steps and target != ir_states.VERBS['clean']: msg = (_('"clean_steps" is only valid when setting target ' 'provision state to %s') % ir_states.VERBS['clean']) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError( msg, status_code=http_client.BAD_REQUEST) if not clean_steps and target == ir_states.VERBS['clean']: msg = (_('"clean_steps" is required when setting target ' 'provision state to %s') % ir_states.VERBS['clean']) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError( msg, status_code=http_client.BAD_REQUEST)
deleted_lines: if configdrive and target != ir_states.ACTIVE: msg = (_('Adding a config drive is only supported when setting ' 'provision state to %s') % ir_states.ACTIVE) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError( msg, status_code=http_client.BAD_REQUEST) if clean_steps and target != ir_states.VERBS['clean']: msg = (_('"clean_steps" is only valid when setting target ' 'provision state to %s') % ir_states.VERBS['clean']) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError( msg, status_code=http_client.BAD_REQUEST) if target == ir_states.ACTIVE: rpc_node.uuid, False, configdrive, topic) elif target == ir_states.REBUILD: pecan.request.rpcapi.do_node_deploy(pecan.request.context, rpc_node.uuid, True, None, topic) if not clean_steps: msg = (_('"clean_steps" is required when setting target ' 'provision state to %s') % ir_states.VERBS['clean']) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError( msg, status_code=http_client.BAD_REQUEST)

added_lines: import wrapt @wrapt.decorator def force_keyword_arguments(wrapped, instance, args, kwargs): if args: raise TypeError('Only keyword arguments are allowed') return wrapped(**kwargs) @force_keyword_arguments

commit_message:
Stop execution if ansible fails to install

If ansible is unable to be installed, then stop execution of
devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh

Change-Id: Ie76ec7ca0615f9166430509727da175034b465a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/76/311876/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Detect when log messages are mis-formatted
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-07 22:38:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/3ad4594099ea60ce01beb3c2a00bebb5e7277409', 'message': 'WIP for finding bad messages

Detect when log messages are mis-formatted.

Change-Id: I25b515ad92c52797ad2e64d09b3269fd16369b66
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-07 23:20:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/e13e8e7fb9e5e020316eed05b65cde76c62e4b43', 'message': "Detect when log messages are mis-formatted

This is a cross-port of part of the fixtures.py file from Nova as
ironic_fixtures.py.

There are a number of things we want to handle with logging in tests:

* Redirect the logging to somewhere that we can test or dump it later.

* Ensure that as many DEBUG messages as possible are actually
   executed, to ensure they are actually syntactically valid (they
   often have not been).

* Ensure that we create useful output for tests that doesn't
  overwhelm the testing system (which means we can't capture the
  100 MB of debug logging on every run).

To do this we create a logger fixture at the root level, which
defaults to INFO and create a Null Logger at DEBUG which lets
us execute log messages at DEBUG but not keep the output.

To support local debugging OS_DEBUG=True can be set in the
environment, which will print out the full debug logging.

There are also a set of overrides for particularly verbose
modules to be even less than INFO.

Cross-port notes:
Updated some files to make tests pass

Removed configuring the standard library logging module in
ironic/db/sqlalchemy/alembic/env.py as this was causing the logger to be
disabled and it would not detect message errors.

Change-Id: I25b515ad92c52797ad2e64d09b3269fd16369b66
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-10-07 23:21:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/67b3e34451037918c4ca637b02619d32ea52c726', 'message': "Detect when log messages are mis-formatted

This is a cross-port of part of the fixtures.py file from Nova as
ironic_fixtures.py.

There are a number of things we want to handle with logging in tests:

* Redirect the logging to somewhere that we can test or dump it later.

* Ensure that as many DEBUG messages as possible are actually
   executed, to ensure they are actually syntactically valid (they
   often have not been).

* Ensure that we create useful output for tests that doesn't
  overwhelm the testing system (which means we can't capture the
  100 MB of debug logging on every run).

To do this we create a logger fixture at the root level, which
defaults to INFO and create a Null Logger at DEBUG which lets
us execute log messages at DEBUG but not keep the output.

To support local debugging OS_DEBUG=True can be set in the
environment, which will print out the full debug logging.

There are also a set of overrides for particularly verbose
modules to be even less than INFO.

Cross-port notes:
Updated some files to make tests pass

Removed configuring the standard library logging module in
ironic/db/sqlalchemy/alembic/env.py as this was causing the logger to be
disabled and it would not detect message errors.

Closes-Bug: #1503086
Change-Id: I25b515ad92c52797ad2e64d09b3269fd16369b66
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-10-08 18:36:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/78df1ce69e8dc704221dc3ab1e08891f711cb618', 'message': "Detect when log messages are mis-formatted

This is a cross-port of part of the fixtures.py file from Nova as
ironic_fixtures.py.

There are a number of things we want to handle with logging in tests:

* Redirect the logging to somewhere that we can test or dump it later.

* Ensure that as many DEBUG messages as possible are actually
   executed, to ensure they are actually syntactically valid (they
   often have not been).

* Ensure that we create useful output for tests that doesn't
  overwhelm the testing system (which means we can't capture the
  100 MB of debug logging on every run).

To do this we create a logger fixture at the root level, which
defaults to INFO and create a Null Logger at DEBUG which lets
us execute log messages at DEBUG but not keep the output.

To support local debugging OS_DEBUG=True can be set in the
environment, which will print out the full debug logging.

There are also a set of overrides for particularly verbose
modules to be even less than INFO.

Cross-port notes:
Updated some files to make tests pass

Removed configuring the standard library logging module in
ironic/db/sqlalchemy/alembic/env.py as this was causing the logger to be
disabled and it would not detect message errors.

Closes-Bug: #1503086
Change-Id: I25b515ad92c52797ad2e64d09b3269fd16369b66

commit_message:
Detect when log messages are mis-formatted

This is a cross-port of part of the fixtures.py file from Nova as
log_fixtures.py.

There are a number of things we want to handle with logging in tests:

* Redirect the logging to somewhere that we can test or dump it later.

* Ensure that as many DEBUG messages as possible are actually
   executed, to ensure they are actually syntactically valid (they
   often have not been).

* Ensure that we create useful output for tests that doesn't
  overwhelm the testing system (which means we can't capture the
  100 MB of debug logging on every run).

To do this we create a logger fixture at the root level, which
defaults to INFO and create a Null Logger at DEBUG which lets
us execute log messages at DEBUG but not keep the output.

To support local debugging OS_DEBUG=True can be set in the
environment, which will print out the full debug logging.

There are also a set of overrides for particularly verbose
modules to be even less than INFO.

Note: This will not catch errors in log messages if 1) The call to the
logger is mocked out, or 2) The unit test never exercises the logging
call.

Cross-port notes:
Removed configuring the standard library logging module in
ironic/db/sqlalchemy/alembic/env.py as this was causing the logger to be
disabled and it would not detect message errors.

Closes-Bug: #1503086
Change-Id: I25b515ad92c52797ad2e64d09b3269fd16369b66
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/57/232257/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.error(_LE('Call to AMT with URI %(uri)s failed: ' 'got Fault %(fault)s'), {'uri': resource_uri, 'fault': fault.text}) LOG.error(_LE("Call to AMT with URI %(uri)s and " "method %(method)s failed: return value " "was %(value)s"), {'uri': resource_uri, 'method': method, 'value': return_value})
deleted_lines: LOG.exception(_LE('Call to AMT with URI %(uri)s failed: ' 'got Fault %(fault)s'), {'uri': resource_uri, 'fault': fault.text}) LOG.exception(_LE("Call to AMT with URI %(uri)s and " "method %(method)s failed: return value " "was %(value)s"), {'uri': resource_uri, 'method': method, 'value': return_value})

commit_message:
DNM/WIP: Testing if '_Remote' code is used

Change-Id: Iffad223c2e08adf9c5ed928fe5dbc2209c416476
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-lib refs/changes/26/537726/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: if self.__class__.__name__.endswith('_Remote'): return self.args[0] else: return six.text_type(self)

commit_message:
WIP/DNM: Initial skeleton support for mypy static type checking

Add some initial framework support for doing static type checking using
the mypy program from the 'mypy' package.

Added to the tox 'pep8' section:
  * Using the python3 interpreter as mypy requires Python 3.
  * Calling the mypy program

Added a few static type information lines to the code.

Added 'typing' as a requirement to requirements.txt

Closes-Bug: #1633756
Depends-On: I29bed962a97c8b28b3feb266d76243da4b4cab7a
Change-Id: I9b875fd5a41bc90f058bef055180a61bd235aab3

subject: DNM/WIP: Convert using str() so types stay consistent
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-30 18:59:54.000000000', 'files': ['ironic_lib/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-lib/commit/75c596c27efd77151e9aea6e275381f9bcf947b4', 'message': "DNM/WIP: Convert using str() so types stay consistent

Previously we were using six.text_type() to convert to a string
representation. This is fine in Python 3 as the type of the string
doesn't change. But in Python 2 it goes from a 'str' type to a
'unicode' type which is not needed for these two cases.

This will make adding of type-hints in the future easier as the types
will stay consistent.

Change-Id: Iea7b67da8c208674d1c5a9d4617bfadb9847d9dd
"}]
commit_message:
DNM/WIP: Convert using str() so types stay consistent

Previously we were using six.text_type() to convert to a string
representation. This is fine in Python 3 as the type of the string
doesn't change. But in Python 2 it goes from a 'str' type to a
'unicode' type which is not needed for these two cases.

This will make adding of type-hints in the future easier as the types
will stay consistent.

Change-Id: Iea7b67da8c208674d1c5a9d4617bfadb9847d9dd

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I9aad306326ad3aefe0c0801f3a1749bac379cdf8

Update master for stable/2023.1

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/2023.1.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/2023.1.

Sem-Ver: feature

added_lines: # Andi Chandler <andi@gowling.com>, 2023. #zanata"POT-Creation-Date: 2023-01-24 23:06+0000\n""PO-Revision-Date: 2023-01-26 10:01+0000\n"msgid "" "A list of strings describing allowed VMDK 'create-type' subformats that will " "be allowed. This is recommended to only include single-file-with-sparse-" "header variants to avoid potential host file exposure due to processing " "named extents. If this list is empty, then no VDMK image types allowed. Note " "that this is currently only checked during image conversion (if enabled), " "and limits the types of VMDK images we will convert from." msgstr "" "A list of strings describing allowed VMDK 'create-type' subformats that will " "be allowed. This is recommended to only include single-file-with-sparse-" "header variants to avoid potential host file exposure due to processing " "named extents. If this list is empty, then no VDMK image types allowed. Note " "that this is currently only checked during image conversion (if enabled), " "and limits the types of VMDK images we will convert from." msgid "Image is a VMDK, but no VMDK createType is specified" msgstr "Image is a VMDK, but no VMDK createType is specified" msgid "Invalid VMDK create-type specified" msgstr "Invalid VMDK create-type specified" msgid "Refusing to process VMDK file as vmdk_allowed_types is empty" msgstr "Refusing to process VMDK file as vmdk_allowed_types is empty" #, python-format msgid "" "Refusing to process VMDK file with create-type of %r which is not in allowed " "set of: %s" msgstr "" "Refusing to process VMDK file with create-type of %r which is not in allowed " "set of: %s" msgid "Unable to determine VMDK create-type" msgstr "Unable to determine VMDK create-type"

This does two things:

1. It makes us check that the QCOW backing_file is unset on those
types of images. Nova and Cinder do this already to prevent an
arbitrary (and trivial to accomplish) host file exposure exploit.
2. It makes us restrict VMDK files to only allowed subtypes. These
files can name arbitrary files on disk as extents, providing the
same sort of attack. Default that list to just the types we believe
are actually useful for openstack, and which are monolithic.

The configuration option to specify allowed subtypes is added in
glance's config and not in the import options so that we can extend
this check later to image ingest. The format_inspector can tell us
what the type and subtype is, and we could reject those images early
and even in the case where image_conversion is not enabled.

Closes-Bug: #1996188

commit_message:
Enforce image safety during image_conversion

This does two things:

1. It makes us check that the QCOW backing_file is unset on those
types of images. Nova and Cinder do this already to prevent an
arbitrary (and trivial to accomplish) host file exposure exploit.
2. It makes us restrict VMDK files to only allowed subtypes. These
files can name arbitrary files on disk as extents, providing the
same sort of attack. Default that list to just the types we believe
are actually useful for openstack, and which are monolithic.

The configuration option to specify allowed subtypes is added in
glance's config and not in the import options so that we can extend
this check later to image ingest. The format_inspector can tell us
what the type and subtype is, and we could reject those images early
and even in the case where image_conversion is not enabled.

Closes-Bug: #1996188
Change-Id: Idf561f6306cebf756c787d8eefdc452ce44bd5e0
(cherry picked from commit 0d6282a01691cecc2798f7858b181c4bb30f850c)
(cherry picked from commit 4967ab6935cfd0274ae801ac943d01909a236a0a)
(cherry picked from commit dc8e5a5cc7f5e9d1b697e520a7533cc90516db1b)
(cherry picked from commit f45b5f024e765f0000884dfec5ac222124cfbc6d)

added_lines: if 'backing-filename' in metadata: LOG.warning('Refusing to process QCOW image with a backing file') raise RuntimeError( 'QCOW images with backing files are not allowed') if metadata.get('format') == 'vmdk': create_type = metadata.get( 'format-specific', {}).get( 'data', {}).get('create-type') allowed = CONF.image_format.vmdk_allowed_types if not create_type: raise RuntimeError(_('Unable to determine VMDK create-type')) if not len(allowed): LOG.warning(_('Refusing to process VMDK file as ' 'vmdk_allowed_types is empty')) raise RuntimeError(_('Image is a VMDK, but no VMDK createType ' 'is specified')) if create_type not in allowed: LOG.warning(_('Refusing to process VMDK file with create-type ' 'of %r which is not in allowed set of: %s'), create_type, ','.join(allowed)) raise RuntimeError(_('Invalid VMDK create-type specified'))

commit_message:
Reintroduce agent bridge resync test

It appears we have changed the test_agent_resync_on_non_existing_bridgetest
main purpose in change 709544[1]. The test is no longer testing on what is
describing it will test, i.e. resync on bridge change. Testing resync on
a bridge change is still important. I feel like what the test is testing
is already covered in _test_agent_events set of tests.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/709544

Change-Id: I8f164c12db7c4c1aa54ba07feede3586e6a19381
(cherry picked from commit 75e83602247360cf10b7b9aa4e53a0135b491cae)

commit_message:
Set fact for run_results returns error when previous validation run is skipped

When validation run is skipped due the unfulfilled condition, run_results variable isn't created, so the set_fact cannot be set properly and returns error which can be interpreted as false negatives. Set_fact task must be corrected so it doesn't fail even if the variable run_results is empty.

Signed-off-by: Veronika Fisarova <vfisarov@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ibb6bf62c0291e27da6b855d7836376a029233138

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I253d07729777dac493eace5f23eee7b30a378dd5

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-09 01:42:04.000000000', 'files': ['sushy/tests/unit/json_samples/bios_zt.json', 'sushy/tests/unit/json_samples/bios_attribute_registry_zthardware.json', 'releasenotes/notes/non-default-language-registries-f73bdecc98ba2cc8.yaml', 'sushy/tests/unit/resources/system/test_bios.py', 'sushy/resources/registry/message_registry_file.py', 'sushy/tests/unit/resources/registry/test_attribute_registry.py', 'sushy/resources/base.py', 'sushy/tests/unit/json_samples/bios_attribute_registry_file_zthardware.json'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/commit/bdbbf86df401fa3a0e154ffbbd0c6174b4c93af5', 'message': 'Handle non-default language for registries

The default value for language in sushy is "en",
in the ZT hardware some registries have "en-US"
as their language, in this case we can't get the
right information.

This commits changes the logic to accept the case
where the registry language starts with the default.

Change-Id: I0c4690925d086af593a691565a66ce90c19be156
(cherry picked from commit fbf44e92c4a820ce0063cfbb4d8a6ad4c224f7ca)
'}]
commit_message:
Handle non-default language for registries

The default value for language in sushy is "en",
in the ZT hardware some registries have "en-US"
as their language, in this case we can't get the
right information.

This commits changes the logic to accept the case
where the registry language starts with the default.

Change-Id: I0c4690925d086af593a691565a66ce90c19be156
(cherry picked from commit fbf44e92c4a820ce0063cfbb4d8a6ad4c224f7ca)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I29873d068166207dbd525c9501cfe8c48883ba7d

Fix owner of private_key secret

The owner of private_key secret in TlsCertificatehandler
should be Unit instead of Application.

commit_message:
Workaround an openstacksdk bug

There was a bug[1] in the openstacksdk implementation that could cause load balancer delete calls to fail. This impacts the octavia dashboard ability to delete load balancers.
This patch adds a workaround for that bug until the impacted versions of openstacksdk have all gone EOL.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/876669

Change-Id: I987211111ebff8d1be50ffd33ba91dc4adf4a709
(cherry picked from commit 5ed6f37519f27335b136340f14f658d49adfe540)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/19/876919/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO(johnsom) Testing for an empty string is a workaround for an # openstacksdk bug present up to the initial # antelope release of openstacksdk. This means the # octavia dashboard would also be impacted. # This test should change to a 406 error once the workaround # is removed. # See: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/876669 def test_empty_accept_header(self): response = self.app.get( self.test_url, status=200, expect_errors=False, headers={constants.ACCEPT: ''}) self.assertEqual(200, response.status_code) self.assertEqual(constants.APPLICATION_JSON, response.content_type)

commit_message:
Add filter to label groups for prometheus

This commit adds the filter 'return_inventory_group' which takes in
a host and the inventory groups varible and returns the group to which
the host belongs based on the following hierarchy:
Controllers -> Compute -> Storage -> Network -> Monitoring.
This group can then be used to add a custom label in prometheus.

Change-Id: I9d979f93fc121e3cabbbeaa9e6031629471a5794
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/30/868930/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def return_inventory_group(host, groups): if host in groups['controllers']: group = 'controllers' elif host in groups['compute']: group = 'compute' elif host in groups['storage']: group = 'storage' elif host in groups['network']: group = 'network' elif host in groups['monitoring']: group = 'monitoring' else: group = 'other' return group "return_inventory_group": return_inventory_group,

commit_message:
release ironic 21.4.0 and branch stable/2023.1

CWI deliverables deadline for antelope is over and at this point every
projects should be branched.

Change-Id: I5c92b115eaba7698046b14509506897a05fccc61
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/73/876573/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - version: 21.4.0 projects: - repo: openstack/ironic hash: 17d97d51ad63a2fb0d4cc7bef448823582dac607 - name: stable/2023.1 location: 21.4.0 cycle-highlights: - Adds support for service role in default policy, intended for service to service communication. service into prometheus, alongside hardware metrics. Previously these were only accessible via statsd. external API clients to horizontal scale. See https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/baremetal/#shards for more information. - Performance on the /v1/ports and /v1/portgroups API list endpoints has been improved.

added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes the iteration to obtain the address_scope linked to a subnet. A network can be linked to more than one subnet (ipv4 and ipv6), but if one of them does not have an address_scope, a null object element access failure occured. See bug `1998104 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1998104>`_.

commit_message:
tests: Replace assertItemsEqual with assertCountEqual

The assertItemsEqual API is no longer current.

1. https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/fd4abac1d6482deab27e4ecd24e9a9d5f5a78cc3
2. https://bugs.python.org/issue17866

Change-Id: I76aab9210de2a1871305d93afc80f1a0542b55f9
(cherry picked from commit 437e743e6cc52fedca277265dc903fc984861a65)

added_lines: <<<<<<< HEAD (76e277 [zed-only] Fix functional tests) ======= # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import datetime from oslo_utils import uuidutils from ironic_inspector.db import api as db from ironic_inspector import introspection_state as istate from ironic_inspector.test import base as test_base from ironic_inspector import utils class TestDBAPI(test_base.NodeStateTest): def setUp(self): super(TestDBAPI, self).setUp() self.node2 = db.create_node(uuid=uuidutils.generate_uuid(), state=istate.States.processing, started_at=datetime.datetime(1, 1, 2), finished_at=None) self.attribute2 = ('fake_attr', 'boo') db.set_attribute(self.node2.uuid, *self.attribute2) self.option2 = ('fake_opt', 'foo') db.set_option(self.node2.uuid, *self.option2) def test_get_nodes(self): nodes = db.get_nodes() self.assertCountEqual([self.node2.uuid, self.uuid], [node.uuid for node in nodes]) def test_get_node_by_uuid(self): node = db.get_node(self.uuid) self.assertEqual(self.uuid, node.uuid) def test_get_node_by_uuid_not_found(self): self.assertRaises( utils.NodeNotFoundInDBError, db.get_node, uuidutils.generate_uuid()) def test_get_node_by_uuid_version_mismatch(self): self.assertRaises( utils.NodeNotFoundInDBError, db.get_node, self.node2.uuid, version_id=123) def test_get_active_nodes(self): nodes = db.get_active_nodes() self.assertCountEqual([self.node2.uuid, self.uuid], [node.uuid for node in nodes]) def test_get_active_nodes_before(self): nodes = db.get_active_nodes(started_before=datetime.datetime(1, 1, 2)) self.assertCountEqual([self.uuid], [node.uuid for node in nodes]) def test_list_nodes_by_attributes(self): attrs = db.list_nodes_by_attributes([self.attribute2]) self.assertCountEqual([self.node2.uuid], [attr.node_uuid for attr in attrs]) def test_list_nodes_options_by_uuid(self): opts = db.list_nodes_options_by_uuid(self.node2.uuid) self.assertCountEqual([self.option2], [(opt.name, opt.value) for opt in opts]) def test_update_node(self): db.update_node(self.node2.uuid, state=istate.States.finished) node2 = db.get_node(self.node2.uuid) self.assertNotEqual(self.node2.state, node2.state) self.assertEqual(istate.States.finished, node2.state) def test_update_node_raises_exception(self): self.assertRaises(utils.NodeNotFoundInDBError, db.update_node, uuidutils.generate_uuid(), error='foo') def tst_add_node(self): db.add_node( uuid=uuidutils.generate_uuid(), state=istate.States.finished) self.assertEqual(2, len(db.get_nodes())) def test_delete_node(self): db.delete_node(self.node2.uuid) self.assertRaises(utils.NodeNotFoundInDBError, db.get_node, self.node2.uuid) self.assertEqual([], db.get_attributes(node_uuid=self.node2.uuid)) self.assertEqual([], db.get_options(uuid=self.node2.uuid)) def test_delete_nodes(self): db.delete_nodes() self.assertEqual([], db.get_nodes()) def test_delete_nodes_finished(self): db.delete_nodes(finished_until=datetime.datetime(4, 4, 4)) self.assertCountEqual([self.uuid, self.node2.uuid], [node.uuid for node in db.get_nodes()]) def test_delete_options(self): db.delete_options(uuid=self.node2.uuid) self.assertEqual([], db.get_options(uuid=self.node2.uuid)) def test_delete_attributes(self): node3 = db.create_node(uuid=uuidutils.generate_uuid(), state=istate.States.finished, started_at=datetime.datetime(1, 1, 3), finished_at=datetime.datetime(1, 1, 4)) attribute3 = ('fake_attr', 'boo') db.set_attribute(node3.uuid, *attribute3) db.delete_attributes(node3.uuid) self.assertEqual( [], db.get_attributes(node_uuid=node3.uuid)) def test_store_introspection_data(self): node = db.create_node(uuid=uuidutils.generate_uuid(), state=istate.States.finished, started_at=datetime.datetime(1, 1, 3), finished_at=datetime.datetime(1, 1, 4)) db.store_introspection_data(node.uuid, {'foo': 'bar'}) res = db.get_introspection_data(node.uuid) self.assertEqual(res['foo'], 'bar') >>>>>>> CHANGE (437e74 tests: Replace assertItemsEqual with assertCountEqual)

commit_message:
Fix API pagination problem in multi servers

This patch fixes the problem regarding pagination of target APIs
in case of running by multiple Tacker servers.

It changes the method of getting paginated records so that they
are able to be done by specifying the last record's id in the last
page.

Closes-Bug: #1978901
Change-Id: Ie0a51f1b837b7426595c40efcbbc022f0ea66f65

commit_message:
Fix enabling epel repo for rpm distributions

The epel packages are installed but their content is purged in the
centos nodes. Removing and reinstalling them when we run tests in
CI to reenable their content.

Change-Id: Ibf1d810a37811151449f79a24bb837db6663cce5

commit_message:
apache2: log true client IP addresses

In the current topology, the horizon app is served behind a haproxt app
acting as a L4 load balancer/proxy. This leads to apache access logs
having the IP addresses of the proxies as client IPs which does not
represent the truth.

This patch is an attempt to mitigate this issue by enabling the proxy
protocol in the communication between apache and haproxy apps for a
more accurate representation of the access logs.

More information can be found in the official apache docs:
https://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/mod_remoteip.html

Closes-Bug: #1829796
Change-Id: I09b9a869489d0d16a2eee19fd579b0f9c52559cb
Signed-off-by: Mert Kırpıcı <mert.kirpici@canonical.com>

added_lines: class NovaComputeVirtMkfsContext(CharmTestCase): def setUp(self): super(NovaComputeVirtMkfsContext, self).setUp(context, TO_PATCH) self.config.side_effect = self.test_config.get self.os_release.return_value = 'zed' def test_cfg_none(self): self.test_config.set('virt-mkfs-cmds', None) ctxt = context.VirtMkfsContext() self.assertEqual({}, ctxt()) def test_cfg_single(self): self.test_config.set('virt-mkfs-cmds', 'default=mkfs.vfat') ctxt = context.VirtMkfsContext() self.assertEqual({'virt_mkfs': 'virt_mkfs = default=mkfs.vfat'}, ctxt()) def test_cfg_multi(self): self.test_config.set('virt-mkfs-cmds', 'default=mkfs.ext4,windows=mkfs.ntfs') ctxt = context.VirtMkfsContext() self.assertEqual({'virt_mkfs': ('virt_mkfs = default=mkfs.ext4\n' 'virt_mkfs = windows=mkfs.ntfs')}, ctxt())

commit_message:
Release venus-tempest-plugin for 2023.1 Antelope

This patch proposes a release for venus-tempest-plugin
to get the latest merged changes out prior to the final
2023.1 Antelope going into effect.

If the team is ready to proceed, please leave a +1 to acknowledge this
release and we will process right away. If the team is working on any
final merges, leave a -1 with some detail on the status and update the
patch with the new commit hash to use when ready.

Patches with no response will be merged by early Friday, March 10.

Signed-off-by: Elod Illes <elod.illes@est.tech>
Change-Id: I4466278b089a348fbbda10fcaa8b648fd0e3369e

subject: Fix focal to jammy series upgrade
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-09 12:23:48.000000000', 'files': ['unit_tests/test_rabbitmq_server_relations.py', 'hooks/rabbitmq_server_relations.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-rabbitmq-server/commit/e381a20f1d5238caf567ac66c13b3a943ecc654d', 'message': "Fix focal to jammy series upgrade

This is a fix/workaround to the package upgrade bug that affects the
charm.  The post-inst package script updates the .erlang.cookie if it is
insecure during the upgrade of rabbit from 3.8 to 3.9.  This breaks the
series-upgrade resulting in a charm erroring on the post-series-upgrade
hook.

This fix works by checking if the .erlang.cookie has changed during the
post-series-upgrade hook and either updating the cookie in peer storage
(if it is insecure) or ensuring that the cookie from peer storage is
written to the .erlang.cookie if it isn't the leader. This ensures that
the cluster continues to work and that the series-upgrade can be
completed across the cluster.

Change-Id: I540ea8da85b3b4326ccb8194f1d8b1050b04eae9
Closes-Bug: #2006484
(cherry picked from commit 55b985f55ca4eb2b2a7229c8dcc70abc8c8940f4)
